I would like to update you on the economic news and some of the work I did in Arizona this past week.   More Jobs & Record Labor Force Participation  Each month of 2019 has shown a positive jobs report and record breaking data proving our U.S. economy remains a strong global leader. The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) released data on Friday showing 164,000 jobs were added into our economy in July, unemployment stayed low at 3.7%, and we reached a record high for labor force participation which hit 163.4 million jobs filled.   If we want to pay for our promises like Social Security and Medicare, we must continue  to grow our economy. To read the full jobs report, click here.  I look forward to seeing how we can fill the newly added jobs from this past month to keep our economy on top.   Great Read ⬇️   The Wall Street Journal Editorial Board released an article this past week that highlighted the new income inequality revisions made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This update is extremely important, as it showed that wages are going up much faster than we originally thought, and we are also seeing savings rates are on the rise.   For too long, economists said we could never reach the statistics we are seeing in our current economy. However, we have now proven that pro-growth policies work, and we must continue to highlight the success and prosperity of all Americans, not just the 1%, who are experiencing the benefits of a strong economy.   To read the full article, click the headline above.   Small Business Spotlights   Thank you Foothills Animal Rescue for your work across communities in Arizona to foster animals in need of a home. We gave them a Small Business Spotlight award for their commitment to saving animals and for their new location in memory of Brynne Smith, a 25-year old who died in a tragic helicopter accident.   This organization, started in 1995 as a foster based organization, has built other locations in Arizona to help more Arizonans foster and adopt. They have helped other pet rescue locations in Arizona too, including recently helping rescue 9 kittens from a local shelter who had no space. Their work is inspiring and Olivia and I had a great time learning more about what they do.   To learn more about how to foster an animal, visit their website here!    We gave Jennifer from Fountain Hills an award for earning accreditation from the National Home Watch Association and for the awesome work her business, Allhouse Home Watch Services, does for our community. Earning accreditation is a huge milestone, congrats to Jennifer!  If you know of an individual or business that you would like to submit a congressional recognition for, be sure to visit my website to fill out a quick online form. We want to make sure all of the stars in our community are being recognized for the important work they are doing for Arizonans.   Upcoming Mobile Office Hours   This Thursday, my District Office team will be at the Arabian Library in Scottsdale to discuss federal casework issues with constituents. If you need help or have any questions regarding federal casework, be sure to come by.   I appreciate you taking the time to read my weekly E-Newsletter. Other bases included in the initial integration are Seymour Johnson AFB in North Carolina, Joint Base Charleston in South Carolina, Shaw AFB in South Carolina, McEntire Joint National Guard Base in South Carolina, Tyndall AFB in Florida, Arnold AFB in Tennessee, and Grissom ARB in Indiana. Integration of 5G technology at Robins, Moody, and Dobbins is big news for Georgia and has the potential to spur greater high-speed internet network investment and economic growth in our communities.  You can read more on this program by .     BEING PREPARED FOR THE NEXT BIG STORM  Hurricane season runs from June to November, and as we all know, being prepared for the next big storm is the greatest deterrent to damage to our homes, businesses, and families.  We all need to take the appropriate steps now to ensure that our families are ready to face any severe weather threats.  The National Hurricane Center recommends that you create a plan for your family, locate a safe room or the safest areas in your home for each severe weather event, make a plan for your pets, and take first aid, CPR or disaster preparedness classes. Taking even these few steps can make all the difference in the world when severe weather strikes.  As we were reminded last year with Hurricane Michael, hurricanes and severe weather are a part of life in Georgia. I urge you to take severe watches and warnings seriously and please plan ahead for your family’s safety and encourage your neighbors to do the same. Click here to watch a special message from the Weather Channel’s Jim Cantore and myself on the importance of being prepared before the next big storm.    Dangerous weather can strike anytime, anywhere. Be sure to make an emergency plan for you and your family.     OUR OFFICES ARE SEEKING INTERNS  Our offices are proud to offer internships to college-aged students and those who have recently graduated from college. Young constituents selected to be interns have the opportunity to gain a comprehensive view of the practices and procedures of a Congressional office and see how the legislative process works up-close. I offer full-time and part-time internships in my Tifton, Warner Robins, and Washington, D.C. offices. In some cases, college students may be able to obtain academic credit.  My offices are currently accepting applications for interns for the fall semester, and I would encourage any students or recent graduates to .   Interns play a vital role in our offices, much like Thomas Oppenheim, a recent intern in our Tifton office.     HERE TO HELP As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact me or a member of my staff on my website by .     Sincerely,   Austin Scott Member of Congress           Social Media Corner:     Offices:  Tifton  (229) 396-5175  Warner Robins  (478) 971-1776  Washington, D.C. The service is teaming with 5G wireless network providers to install commercial network infrastructure on 10 bases now, with more to come.      “Watchdog Praises Afghan A-29 Training as Moody Program Winds Down” (Air Force Magazine) – The US Air Force trains Afghan Super Tucano pilots at Moody AFB, Ga. Sincerely, Elijah E. CummingsMember of Congress    Community Announcements During periods of extreme heat, the Baltimore City Health Department declares a Code Red Extreme Heat Alert. During Code Red days the city opens cooling centers, you can get information about heat advisories and find a cooling center by calling 311 in Baltimore City or by visiting the Health Department’s website. Howard County, Baltimore County and other counties across Maryland also open up cooling centers during days with extreme heat, to find a list of cooling centers near you call 211 or click here.  During days with extreme heat, the Health Department recommends that you:   Drink plenty of water and avoid alcohol and caffeine Reduce outside activities and stay inside in air-conditioned locations Never leave children or pets alone in closed vehicles, even for short periods Check on older, sick, or frail neighbors who may need help responding to the heat  You should also watch out for signs of heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Their symptoms include:   Confusion Hot, dry, flushed skin or cool and clammy skin Lightheadedness Nausea  If any of these symptoms occur, you should call 911 immediately.    In the District   Congressman Elijah E. Cummings with participants in the University of Maryland Baltimore Summer Bioscience Internship Program and the Youthworks Program. Earlier this week, I had an amazing time meeting with students of the University of Maryland Baltimore Summer Bioscience Internship Program and the Youthworks Program. Upon my urging 11 years ago, the University of Maryland Baltimore started the Internship Program to give students in my district hands-on experience in the health and science fields. Because of this program, high school and undergraduate students are working in research labs, Shock Trauma, and several other units at the University of Maryland Medical Center, learning invaluable lessons and earning pay. The hard work and dedication of these energized young people fuel me.      Congressman Elijah E. Cummings joins Senator Ben Cardin, Senator Chris Van Hollen, and Congressman John Sarbanes to announce $125 million in federal funding for the Howard Street Tunnel expansion project. On July 23, the Maryland Congressional Delegation announced $125 million in federal funding for the Howard Street Tunnel expansion. The project, which aims to improve freight movement out of the Port of Baltimore, is central to the success of the region's economy. This is one of the top 10 largest projects ever funded by the U.S. Department of Transportation's Infrastructure For Rebuilding America grant program. The project has been a priority for me and the entire delegation for many years, and despite the many challenges we have faced, we have worked closely with the State of Maryland and CSX to support an effective public-private partnership that will be able to modernize this critical piece of infrastructure.    Congressman Elijah E. Cummings speaks to representatives from Wells Fargo, NeighborWorks America, and Neighborhood Housing Services of Baltimore at the launch of the NeighborhoodLIFT program in Baltimore. On July 19, I had the pleasure of speaking to representatives from Wells Fargo, NeighborWorks America, and Neighborhood Housing Services of Baltimore before they launched the NeighborhoodLIFT program in Baltimore. The program provides $15,000 down payment assistance grants and face-to-face homeownership counseling for eligible Baltimore homebuyers. You can learn more and find out if you qualify here.    In Washington   Congressman Elijah E. Cummings joins Senator Ben Cardin, Senator Chris Van Hollen, and Congressman Jamie Raskin to award the Congressional Badge of Bravery to United States Capitol Police Special Agents Crystal Griner and David Bailey. On July 16, I had the immense honor to award the Congressional Badge of Bravery to United States Capitol Police Special Agents Crystal Griner, a constituent of mine from Gwynn Oak, and David Bailey of Silver Spring for their heroic actions during the shooting at a Congressional baseball game practice in 2017. Their quick actions and bravery saved lives that day.    Congressman Cummings questions the National Transportation Safety Board about Bus Safety. Click here to watch the question line.  Last week, I participated in a Subcommittee on Highways and Transit hearing “Examining the Federal Role in Improving School Bus Safety.” At the hearing, I asked Dr. Kristin Poland, the Deputy Director of the Office of Highway Safety at the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), questions about NTSB’s report and recommendations regarding a November 1, 2016 school bus accident in Baltimore in which six people were killed. We have to ensure that this cannot happen again.    Community Spotlight    Ms. Gloria Cai of Howard County was selected to be part of the 2019 National Youth Orchestra. Earlier this month, I was delighted to learn that Ms. Gloria Cai of Howard County was named to be a part of the 2019 National Youth Orchestra program this summer. Ms. Cai will tour internationally with the orchestra to promote intercultural dialogue through music by playing her cello. The recognition of Ms. Cai’s talent is inspiring, and I expect that she will create great work in the future.    Legislative Update The Safeguarding Student Veterans Act:On July 26,  Congressman Ted Yoho (FL-03) and I introduced the Safeguarding Student Veterans Act to protect student veterans using the Post 9/11 GI Bill. In recent years, we have seen a wave of abrupt closures of colleges in Maryland and around the country, particularly those operating for-profit. These sudden closings have disproportionately impacted student veterans, leaving these student veterans bearing a major burden and asking ‘what’s next?’ The Safeguarding Student Veterans Act increases coordination between the Department of Education and the Department of Veterans Affairs in order to empower veterans to make the best decision when choosing their school. Our veterans have served our country, and we must honor the sacrifices they made as they transition back into civilian life and seek to better themselves through education. The Opportunity Zone Lead Remediation Impact Act of 2019: This month, I also introduced the Opportunity Zone Lead Remediation Impact Act of 2019 with Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib to eradicate lead poisoning in Census tracks designated as Opportunity Zones. Opportunity Zones were created as part of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act to provide tax incentives for investment in underserved areas and brought a wonderful chance for many disinvested communities to receive the economic support needed to lift their poorest residents out of poverty and into the middle class. However, the program did not provide any guidelines to ensure investments made within Opportunity Zones provided for better health outcomes for their residents.  This legislation changes that and would ensure a positive impact on the overall health of residents by eradicating lead poisoning in Opportunity Zones.                                Washington, DC 2163 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515202-225-4741 Baltimore Office 1010 Park Av. # 105Baltimore, MD 21201410-685-9199 Catonsville Office 754 Frederick RoadCatonsville, MD 21228410-719-8777 Ellicott City Office 8267 Main St. # 102Ellicott, MD 21043410-465-8259              | Privacy Policy

Louisianans are no strangers to storms, and I know we’ll pull through.  Please do what you can now to protect yourself, your family, your neighbors and your pets. Click here or the photo below to watch my message on Tropical Storm Barry.    Preparing for Tropical Storm Barry  Pack an emergency preparedness kit.  This should include food, water, medications, flashlights, batteries and a first-aid kit.  Also, make sure your vehicle has a full tank of gas.  Click here to view FEMA’s recommended list of supplies. Review your evacuation zones.  If you are advised to evacuate, please do so immediately.  Even if you are not in an evacuation zone, plan ahead and have a route ready in case you need to evacuate.  Click here to find the latest news on evacuations and important information regarding evacuation routes. Avoid floodwaters. Strong currents can carry people and small vehicles away.  Floodwaters can contain chemicals and waste that can cause lethal illnesses. Stay informed.  Tune in to your local television and radio stations to stay up to date on the latest developments.  Follow the National Weather Service on Twitter to receive updates on the storm: @NWSNewOrleans     Click here to unsubscribe from future newsletters                    Washington, DCSR-416, Russell Senate BuildingWashington, DC 20510Phone: (202) 224-4623Fax: (202) 228-0447

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }            News From Congressman Ben Cline                    Sixth District Perspectives  with Congressman Ben Cline  The halls of the Capitol were supposed to be quiet week before last, during what is commonly known as a “District Work Period” for Congress. Members spend time working in their local offices, meeting with constituents, visiting local businesses, or speaking with community groups about local issues of importance. It’s a great opportunity to reconnect with and report back to the voters who we represent in Washington and who we fight for each and every day.  What we normally don't do during District Work Periods is consider legislation. That’s because almost no one is there to cast a vote on the bills. It’s understood that the Speaker will not try to push legislation through when a bill's opponents are all back home in their districts. Normally, the Speaker shows respect to other Members by waiting for them to return to Washington. Respect for the institution of Congress and respect for debate is critical for the government envisioned by our founding fathers to function.  Speaker Nancy Pelosi, however, decided to toss aside the the historic courtesies that have been shown to Members for centuries. Without calling Members back to vote, the Democrat leadership tried to pass H.R. 2157, a spending bill to address several natural disasters that occurred in the past few years. While I support efforts to provide assistance to communities who have been impacted by natural disasters, this brazen attempt to ram this bill through without any debate is symptomatic of just how broken Washington has become.  After several Republicans drove back to Washington to object to efforts to move the bill, it became clear why they didn’t want debate about what was in it. Amazingly, less than 30 percent of the $19.188 billion package has anything to do with actual disaster assistance. The rest of the bill was full of pork-barrel spending for pet projects and other non-emergency functions. Debating the bill also would have given Members the chance to understand that 86 percent of the funding in this bill was not even requested by the Trump Administration. Members should have also been aware that the Disaster Relief Fund (DRF) was funded at $29 billion at the end of April, with projections of $18.2 billion in the fund at the end of the fiscal year.  While H.R. 2157 eventually did pass by a vote of 354-58, House Democrats failed to identify a way to pay for it without adding to our national debt. I will continue to vote against wasteful spending and demand fiscal responsibility in Washington in all areas. If we can find ways to balance our state budgets and our family budgets, I believe it is time for the federal government to follow suit.  In other action last week, the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on the Constitution, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties held a hearing to promote increased access to abortion. During the hearing, we heard from witnesses on both sides of the ideological spectrum. Amazing testimony came from Melissa Odhen, who survived an abortion procedure. As an adult, Melissa has made it her life’s mission to prevent abortions and stand up for the right to life. As a co-sponsor of the Born Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act, I am grateful to Melissa for sharing her story, and I will continue to advocate for the protection of life.  I also took to the House floor Tuesday to introduce language into H.R. 6, the DREAM Act, which would have prevented known criminals, gang members, terrorists, and other public safety threats from gaining legal status through this legislation. The perverse effect of H.R. 6 is that these public safety threats who could be denied a green card will still be free to stay in the country – as if the U.S. is a sanctuary nation. I made a motion that would have made it easier for Department of Homeland Security to deny gang members’ applications by making it an eligibility requirement that an alien not be a gang member, and by explicitly permitting DHS to consider the information found in gang databases. It would have ensured that criminals, gang members, and those who are terrorists and other public safety threats are referred for a determination of removal from the United States. I am disappointed that most Democrats in the House rejected this necessary change to the bill.  Finally, this week ended with quiet contemplation. On June 6, 1944, more than 150,000 allied troops stormed the beaches of Normandy, France, in the largest seaborne invasion in history. The success of D-Day laid the foundations for the liberation of Western Europe, the defeat of Nazi Germany, and ultimate victory in World War II. On Thursday, I participated in a solemn ceremony at the National D-Day Memorial in Bedford commemorating the 75th anniversary of the D-Day invasion.  I thank all veterans for their service, but I especially want to thank the men of Bedford for their courage and sacrifice on that day 75 years ago. Twenty-two men from Bedford were killed during the invasion and subsequent fighting. It was the largest loss of life on a proportional basis of any town in the United States. Their bravery and sacrifice continue to secure the freedoms we enjoy today. May we never forget the men of Bedford and the courage of all those who have fought for the greatest Nation on Earth, the United States of America.                 Washington D.C. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office estimates hurricane winds and storm related flooding will cost the U.S. economy $54 billion this year. The toll on our communities will continue to worsen with each coming season as storms get stronger as a result of rising global temperatures and sea levels caused by surging greenhouse gas emissions. Looking back on the devastating effects of Hurricanes Florence and Michael last year, it is imperative we take the necessary precautions to protect our families, homes, businesses and communities.  The following information was compiled with resources from federal agencies and will help you prepare for severe weather in Connecticut.  Be Prepared  Every family should have a plan to respond to an upcoming storm. I encourage you to use the information below to help you craft your own plan.   Discuss the types of hazards or storms that your family and home may encounter. What supplies would you need? How would your family stay in contact with each other? Keep important documents in a secure place or create password-protected digital copies. Identify safe areas for your family in the event of a storm hazard. These areas may not be in your home but could be elsewhere in your community. Familiarize yourself with evacuation routes, especially if you live close to the coast. Determine escape routes from your home and other places to meet. Craft an evacuation plan should circumstances require you to leave town. Appoint an out-of-state friend as a single point of contact for all family members to check in with at designated times. Make a plan for your pets in the event of an evacuation. Some hotels do not allow pets, but most do in the case of emergency. Post emergency telephone numbers by your phones. Make sure your children know how and when to call 9-1-1. Create a disaster supply kit. Stock it with non-perishable emergency food, water, first-aid necessities, supplies, flashlights, a battery-powered radio and extra batteries. Remember to fully charge any electronic devices you may need in the lead up to the storm.         Click to watch my YouTube video on storm preparedness with Jim Cantore from The Weather Channel         Stay Informed The State of Connecticut uses the CT Alert Emergency Notification System to notify residents of emergencies. This system allows you to receive updates via text or email and will notify you of changing weather, evacuation orders, and other timely information, even if you lose power or do not have radio or tv access. Click here to register for these updates.  I also encourage you to sign up for my e-newsletter for important updates. I will pass along helpful information in the event of a major storm. Please remember that although I will send email updates as quickly as circumstances will allow, your local first responders and Emergency Operations Centers will be able to provide the best information and assistance should a dangerous situation arise. Today, we honor the men and women who have made so many sacrifices to defend our freedom. We remember the fallen, and thank each of our service members for your strength and courage in the fight to keep this nation safe.     It was great to join neighbors in Fountain Hills today to celebrate our fallen service members this Memorial Day. God bless our military and their families.   Combating Valley Fever   I am pleased to announce the FORWARD Act, legislation to combat Valley Fever and support research to find a cure has been introduced in the House and Senate.  Since being in Congress, we have created the Valley Fever Task Force, a caucus to help educate Members of Congress about this orphan fungal disease found in the Southwest. Now, we have introduced legislation that helps to combat this disease. My colleague Rep. Kevin McCarthy and I have held round tables, met with researchers and scientists, and have learned so much about this disease. It is great to see this legislation bring attention to this disease, and to help those infected.   Every year, our community sees increased rates of Valley Fever. This legislation pushes for a breakthrough in research, it also introduces the first blockchain pilot program for collecting data for fungal diseases. As scientists are getting closer to a cure for valley fever [soon a vaccination for our pets], I look forward to seeing how the critical resources provided in this legislation will positively impact the southwest. We are extremely hopeful that a cure is in our near future.   If you would like to learn more about the legislation, click here.   Celebrating the 19th Amendment   100 years ago, the 19th Amendment passed the U.S. House of Representatives to give women the right to vote. The right to vote is one of our nation's most sacred rights, giving all individuals an equal voice in our elections. I wore a yellow rose in honor of this anniversary, just as supporters of women's suffrage did a century ago.   Securing Retirement Savings   This week, I voted for the SECURE Act, bipartisan legislation to help Americans save for retirement. We must all be thinking about our future plans, and how we are saving for them. This legislation is a great step in the right direction, but we still have more work to do to ensure we can all have peace of mind when retiring. To watch me speak about this legislation on the House Floor, click here.   Sincerely, David Schweikert                            WASHINGTON, DC OFFICE 1526 Longworth HOBWashington, D.C. 20515Phone: (202) 225-2190Fax: (202) 225-0096 SCOTTSDALE DISTRICT OFFICE 14500 N. body: Congressman Guy Reschenthaler, Representing the 14th District of Pennsylvania *Opposing Judiciary Democrats' Vote to Hold AG Barr in Contempt* [image = [link 1] This partisan vote to hold the Attorney General in contempt was nothing more than an attempt to publicly shame and discredit Mr. Barr for political purposes. To say that I'm disappointed in the direction of this committee is an understatement. I was sent here to get things done, and I feel like my colleagues across the aisle have been chasing a ghost for the last two years. During that time, we've suffered from an opioid pandemic. I say pandemic because it's everywhere in the United States, and it's killing thousands of individuals. We have real problems to address in our country, such as immigration. By moving to a merit-based system, we could bring our country into step with the rest of the industrialized world. I have two bipartisan bills that I'm introducing with my Democratic colleagues that could really make a difference (H.R. 2368 [link 2] and H.R. [link 3]2348 [link 4]). But instead, we've been engaging in political theater, bringing in props, and just chasing this ghost for the last two years. We've already pointed out that Attorney General Barr has been incredibly transparent and the Department of Justice has been more than accommodating, but Chairman Nadler continues to move at an unprecedented speed toward the Democrats' true goal: impeaching President Trump. To watch the full clip of my remarks, please click here [link 5]. *Introducing Legislation to Support Law Enforcement Officers, Improve Mental Health Care* In an effort to improve mental health treatment and support for our nation's law enforcement officers, I recently joined with Rep. Madeleine Dean (PA-04) to introduce H.R. 2368, the *Supporting and Treating Officers in Crisis (STOIC) Act.* This bipartisan legislation will reform and expand an existing grant program to better address the mental health and support needs of law enforcement officers, especially as it relates to suicide prevention. Law enforcement officers put their lives on the line every day to protect our communities. These men and women routinely endure extremely stressful situations, yet the federal government does little to address the consequences of this taxing work. This stress can cause high blood pressure and post-traumatic stress disorder, and has resulted in a suicide rate that is 50 percent higher than the national average. I am proud to work with Congresswoman Dean to fix this wrong and support police officers and their families. According to the National Study of Police Suicides, officers are 2.5 times more likely to die from suicides than from homicides. This sobering statistic means that law enforcement officers are more likely to die from suicide than in the line of duty. The *STOIC Act* would address this problem by allowing family-services grant program funding to be used to establish suicide prevention programs and support officers suffering stress and mental health issues. The program would be authorized at $7.5 million annually for Fiscal Years 2020 through 2024. This legislation has been endorsed by: - Fraternal Order of Police [link 6] - National Sheriff's Association - Major County Sheriffs of America - National Association of Police Organizations [link 7] - American Foundation for Suicide Prevention [link 8] - National District Attorney's Association - Sergeants Benevolent Association [link 9] It is time for us to take care of those who take care of us. I hope my colleagues in the House will prioritize the mental health of our law enforcement officers by supporting the *STOIC Act.* *Since coming to Congress, it has been an honor to represent sailors, airmen, marines, and soldiers. Last week, I welcomed Secretary of the Navy Richard Spencer in my D.C. office, where we discussed the importance of maritime superiority, a strengthened fleet, and increased readiness.* [image = *Voting Against Legislation to Cripple the U.S. Energy Sector* Last week, I voted to protect jobs and further economic growth by opposing H.R. 9, a bill that would prevent President Donald J. Trump from withdrawing from the Obama Administration's costly Paris Agreement commitments. I support President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. This was an unfair deal that put our country at a disadvantage by giving a free pass to India and China, while forcing unrealistic demands on our national economy. As our nation reaches its energy dominance and continues to reduce emissions through innovation, House Democrats want us to put our economic growth, jobs, and security at risk by forcing President Trump to implement the Paris Agreement. The U.S. has already seen the largest absolute decline in emissions among all countries since 2000, according to the International Energy Agency. Between 2000 and 2014, our nation reduced emissions by more than 18 percent. The Paris Agreement would yield the following outcomes by 2035: - An overall average shortfall of nearly 400,000 jobs; - An average manufacturing shortfall of over 200,000 jobs; - A total income loss of more than $20,000 for a family of four; - An aggregate gross domestic product loss of over $2.5 trillion; and - Increases in household electricity expenditures between 13 percent and 20 percent. I opposed H.R. 9 to protect jobs for hardworking Pennsylvanians and the families who rely on them. I support an energy proposal that expands and improves our energy infrastructure, invests in new and emerging technologies, and increases our nation's role in promoting global energy security. *I was honored to welcome Lithuania's Ambassador to the US Rolandas Krisciunas to my DC office this week, where we discussed opportunities for cooperation between our nations.* [image = *Introducing Legislation to Protect Puppies* I recently joined with my colleagues Reps. Brian Fitzpatrick (PA-01), Charlie Crist (FL-13), and Jim McGovern (MA-02) to introduce the *Puppy Protection Act*, which will provide better protection for puppies by improving standards for federally licensed commercial dog breeders. I have long championed legislation that protects our nation's animals from abuse and neglect. By moving toward more humane standards for commercial dog breeders in our country, this bill will promote animal welfare and provide enhanced protections for the puppies throughout our country. I hope these efforts will improve the lives of our dogs and defend these creatures who cannot defend themselves. Too many of our dogs currently suffer from inhumane conditions, but I look forward to working with my colleagues Representatives Fitzpatrick, Crist, and McGovern to provide protections for these animals in the future. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) regulates federally licensed commercial dog breeders that sell dogs wholesale to retail pet stores and commercial brokers, or directly to consumers over the Internet under the *Animal Welfare Act.* While the *Animal Welfare Act *is meant to ensure dogs in federally licensed facilities are treated humanely, the current regulations fall far short. The *Puppy Protection Act* creates stronger standards for veterinary care, housing, breeding practices, and specific standards for socialization and placement of retired breeding dogs. The* Puppy Protection Act* will not impact family pets, livestock, or hobbyist breeders. "We envision a day when a puppy will never again find her paws and legs trapped in the wire flooring of a stacked cage at a puppy mill. The *Puppy Protection Act* will strengthen baseline standards of care that must be provided by large commercial dog breeder. Thank you to the leadership of Reps. Fitzpatrick, Crist, McGovern, and Reschenthaler for introducing this important bipartisan measure to improve the living conditions of dogs and puppies. We will fight to support its passage." - *Sara Amundson, president of the Humane Society Legislative Fund* "The *Puppy Protection Act* will help improve the lives of hundreds of thousands of dogs kept in inhumane conditions by federally licensed commercial breeders. Current regulations allow dogs in federally licensed facilities to spend their entire lives in filthy, crowded cages stacked on top of one another with no access to adequate veterinary care or regular exercise. We thank Representatives Fitzpatrick, Crist, Reschenthaler, and McGovern for their continued leadership on the *Puppy Protection Act* and call upon USDA to ensure the thorough and proper enforcement of the *Animal Welfare Act*." - *Richard Patch, vice president of federal affairs for the ASPCA* "AWI thanks Reps. Fitzpatrick, Crist, Reschenthaler, and McGovern for their efforts to update and enhance the requirements for the care of dogs in breeding facilities. Such improvements are long overdue for both breeding facilities and all entities regulated under the *Animal Welfare Act* - *Nancy Blaney, Director of Government Affairs at **Animal Welfare Institute* *Thanks to the PA Association of Community Bankers for meeting to discuss ways to work with our local banks to create jobs in our communities.* [image = *Introducing Bipartisan Legislation to Allow Servicemembers to Sue for Medical Malpractice* I recently joined with my colleagues Reps. Jackie Speier (D-CA), Richard Hudson (R-NC), Jamie Raskin (D-MD), Ted Lieu (D-CA), Markwayne Mullin (R-OK), and Charlie Crist (D-FL), to introduce the *Sergeant First Class Richard Stayskal Military Medical Accountability Act* *of* *2019*, which would allow military servicemembers to bring claims against the federal government for instances of medical malpractice unrelated to their military duties. SFC Stayskal developed terminal lung cancer after being misdiagnosed in a military health facility. America's servicemembers and their families make tremendous sacrifices to protect our freedoms, yet we deny them the ability to seek justice for injury or death caused by negligence at military medical facilities. I look forward to working with my colleagues in a bipartisan manner to correct this wrong. Our troops deserve better. For nearly 70 years, servicemembers have not been able to bring claims against military medical providers after being misdiagnosed, mistreated, or subjected to botched surgeries, even though this malpractice occurred in health care settings in which almost all other Americans have that right. This legislation seeks to fix the Feres Doctrine by allowing servicemembers and their families to sue the military for medical malpractice. It is important to note that this legislation excludes treatment received in combat, including battalion aid stations or other medical treatment locations deployed in an area of armed conflict. This bill is supported by the following organizations: - Military Officers Association of America (MOAA) - Blue Star Families - Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America (IAVA) - National Military Family Association - The Retired Enlisted Association (TREA) - Sea Service Family Foundation - Service Women's Action Network - Center for Law and Military Policy - Protect Our Defenders (POD) ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] [link 9] Contact information: Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 531 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-2065 Greensburg Office 700 Pellis Road, Suite 1 Greensburg, PA 15601 Phone: (724) 219-4200 Washington District Office 14 S. subject: Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 4.1.19
body: The Ninth District: On the Cutting Edge of Biological Engineering for Health Care When not in Washington, D.C., voting in the U.S. House of Representatives during March, I was able to visit several sites where exciting research projects are underway. Previously, I wrote about some of them at Virginia Tech. More recently, I visited a farm site where scientific accomplishments once seemingly from the realm of a futuristic novel promise to make a difference in our daily lives. You may remember Dolly the sheep, the first mammal cloned with an adult cell. Dolly was cloned in Scotland in 1996 and died in 2003, and if you ever visit the National Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh, you can see her taxidermied remains. The technology that created her continues to be advanced, refined, and put to new uses. Some of that work is being done here in Southwest Virginia, thanks to a connection with Dolly: Virginia Tech had a stake in the entity that cloned her. While the company that cloned Dolly no longer exists, in the years since she was cloned, related research has continued in our area, with the Blacksburg-based company Revivicor, which spun off from the company that created Dolly, developing technology for cloning and genetically modifying pigs. During my visit to the farm where the genetically-modified cloned pigs are kept, which is located in the Ninth District, I saw that the pigs do not look different from any other pig. They are treated well, almost like pets. Unlike normal pigs, however, they potentially hold new advances in biological engineering for health purposes. For example, they potentially offer a new source for organs that can be transplanted to the people in need of them. These special pigs organs have similarities to ours that could make them suitable for transplanting, providing a new source of organs for people waiting on them. People with diabetes may also stand to benefit from this research, as certain cells from these genetically-modified pigs could be transplanted into a human pancreas to increase insulin production for those who need it. Cloning genetically-modified pigs offer more than just a new source of organs for transplant. Scientists are working on ways to use cloned pigs to help people overcome particular food allergies. The alpha-gal allergy has become more prevalent in the southeastern United States in recent years; one estimate suggests that up to 30 percent of people in the region have it. It is spread by Lone Star tick bites, which introduce alpha-gal molecules into the body. People who acquire this allergy suffer adverse effects, such as itching, swelling, and anaphylaxis, when eating red meat such as beef, lamb, pork, and venison. Essentially any four-legged animals commonly brought to the dinner table become off-limits to a person with the alpha-gal allergy, even if he or she had previously been able to consume them. It imposes disappointing dietary restrictions on many. Other deleterious effects impact the health of people with the alpha-gal allergy. Exposure to other products that come from mammals, not just food, can trigger allergic reactions. As an example, a small percentage of people would be affected by the gelatin sometimes used as an ingredient in medical products, such as capsules. Further, there are some indications that the allergy may contribute to heart disease. Now how do these cloned pigs relate to this problem? By splicing genes, eliminating the alpha-gal gene and adding others, researchers can create genetically-modified cloned pigs that do not produce the alpha-gal protein. Products derived from them, from food to medications, will not trigger allergic reactions. It is exciting to know that this research, which could make a positive difference in the lives of men and women around the world, is being done in our backyard. The work I discussed in this column is just the tip of the iceberg of potential benefits. Of course, as always with new fields of scientific research, propriety and ethics must be taken into consideration. The biological engineering sector has a firm foothold in Southwest Virginia, drawing people and investment into our region. Just as there is a long way between Dolly the sheep and the progress yielded in these cloned pigs, the successes of this industry in our region may shape our world in new and unlikely ways. If you have questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to contact my office. You can call my Abingdon office at 276-525-1405 or my Christiansburg office at 540-381-5671. To reach my office via email, please visit my website at

name: Congressman Bob Latta
subject: The Latta Letter - March 3, 2019
body: Friends, I hope you all stayed safe the past few weeks. Sustained winds of 40-50 mph and gusts of up to 65 mph left thousands without power in our region and across the state of Ohio. We thank our first responders and electrical workers for their hard work to keep people safe and mitigate the damage. In Washington, there have been a number of proposals from Democrats that received much attention. One proposal that has been in the news lately has been the "Green New Deal." The Green New Deal is an irresponsible proposal that would cost $93 trillion dollars over the next ten years and change much of our way of life. To put that cost in perspective, its $600,000 per American family. In addition, Democrats introduced Medicare-for-All healthcare legislation this week. Make no mistake, this is government-run, single-payer health care. Medicare-for-All would cost $32 trillion dollars, end employer-sponsored health care (throwing 500,000 of my constituents off of their healthcare plans), and drastically reduce access to health care in rural communities. Its important we work in a bipartisan way in Washington to find solutions to the problems that Americans face, including protecting the environment and addressing rising health care costs. However, these proposals would be devastating to the constituents I represent, and I cant support them. An update on other recent happenings: In Congress Breaking Down Barriers for Veteran STEM Careers Veterans have given so much to our nation, and its important that we keep the promises made to them. One way we can help is in the transition from the military to civilian life. Its not always easy for members of our military to make a switch to a civilian career. This week, the House passed the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act, legislation to boost veteran career opportunities in the STEM and computer science fields. Through educational opportunities, data-driven outreach initiatives, and traineeship programs, this piece of legislation will help to dismantle the current barriers our heroes face upon transitioning into a civilian career. Closing the Digital Divide I am proud to serve as the Republican Leader on the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Communication and Technology. One of my main priorities is closing the digital divide and increasing access to broadband  especially in our rural areas. Over the past few years, weve worked in Congress to help provide the tools to provide more Americans with high-speed Internet. Last week, a draft Federal Communications Commission (FCC) report showed that actions by the FCC and Congress are working. According to the draft report, the number of Americans lacking access to high-speed broadband has fallen by 25%. The majority of those Americans live in rural areas. Whats important about these facts is it shows efforts to reduce regulatory burdens and support investment are helping more Americans gain access to high-speed Internet. As I represent a number of rural areas, I know it will make a significant difference inside family homes and for businesses on Main Street in rural communities. Its important we keep this momentum going. Protecting Local Radio Our local radio stations in Northwest and West Central Ohio provide us with emergency alerts, important weather updates, and keep us in-the-know on the latest news. They are integral parts of our communities. However, various fee and royalty proposals in Congress have threatened the way that these radio stations are able to operate. This week, I cosponsored a bipartisan resolution, the Local Radio Freedom Act, which opposes any fees, taxes, and royalties on broadcasting performances for local radio stations. The Local Radio Freedom Act recognizes the potential damaging effects of fees and royalties and demonstrates the broad bipartisan support for local radio stations and their listeners across our country.  Time is Right for Data Privacy Legislation This week, I participated in an Energy and Commerce Subcommittee hearing on data privacy issues. I talked about how the time is right to pass bipartisan federal privacy legislation. My opening statement is below, but you can watch the video of the hearing as well. I spoke at 1:46. Here's what I said: Last Congress, the Energy and Commerce Committee held nearly a dozen hearings discussing privacy and security issues. That includes much publicized hearings where we heard from the CEOs of Facebook and Twitter about how those companies collect, safeguard, and use data. From those hearings, it was clear that while these companies provide a service that Americans like, consumers arent always clear about what happens with their personal information. With the California law slated to take effect at the beginning of next year, time is of the essence. In divided government, its not always easy to tackle the tough problems, but I believe the time is right to work together on a federal data privacy solution. Both consumer groups and business organizations have come on board in calling for a national standard. We all agree that consumers should have transparency and accountability, and that we want to ensure that the United States stays the prime location for innovation and technology. True Blue Award I was honored to receive the True Blue Award this week for my strong record supporting family values -100% on the 2018 Family Resource Council scorecard. In a week when the Senate voted down the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act, its never been more important to stand up on these issues. These are the values of Ohios 5th Congressional District, and Ill continue to back policies that protect life, liberty, and religious freedom. Latta receiving the 'True Blue' Award from FRC President Tony Perkins Around the District Tours, Meetings, and Celebrations in Ohios 5th District Over the last few weeks, Ive made a number of stops to talk with people in communities around the district. In Mercer County, I had the pleasure of attending the Celina-Mercer Chamber of Commerce annual banquet. I also attended the Henry County Community Improvement Corporation's annual meeting and reception. This event serves as an opportunity to celebrate the contributions of those who have made a lasting impact in the area. In Lucas County, I toured K-Limited Carrier, a liquid bulk carrying company, where I was able to see their operations up close. In addition, I toured the West Suburban Animal Hospital where I was able to see how the 6 vets at the facility - and 22 in their system - help take care of pets and other animals. One of my favorite sayings is, If you want a friend in Washington, get a dog. Needless to say, I have a soft spot for the men and women that provide treatment for our pets.  FFA Celebration in Wyandot County I attended a celebration of the 91st anniversary of Future Farmers of America at the Wyandot County Ag Leaders Breakfast. FFA is a tremendous organization that helps our youth prepare for careers in science, business, and agricultural technology. The breakfast was put on by the Ohio FFA chapters from Carey, Mohawk, Riverdale, and Upper Sandusky schools, and it was inspiring to see such great leadership from local FFA chapters in the region. Congressional Art Competition Reminder A reminder that the deadline for submission for this year's Congressional Art Competition is on Monday, March 4. That's TOMORROW! High school students that live or attend school in Ohios Fifth Congressional District are encouraged to submit a piece of art for this years competition. All artwork will be displayed at Owens Community College in Perrysburg Township. More than 650,000 high school students have participated in the competition nationwide since it began in 1982. The winning piece will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol Building in Washington, D.C. for one year, and three honorable mention pieces will be displayed in my district offices. More information is available here. Defending the Most Innocent It was a dark day on Monday in the U.S. Senate as commonsense legislation, the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection, was defeated. The Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act would require that a baby who survives an attempted abortion be provided the exact same health care as a baby born prematurely. There is no justification for voting against this legislation. Its the morally right decision to pass this bill. Its backed by science. Its supported by nearly four out of every five Americans. Instead, 44 Democrats voted against the legislation and supported a position completely outside of the mainstream. I thank Democratic Senators Joe Manchin, Doug Jones, and Bob Casey for bucking their party on this important issue  but its disgraceful that they werent joined by more of their colleagues. Recently, I authored an op-ed on the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act and the shocking comments made by Virginia Governor Ralph Northam on the abortion issue. This comes after the state of New York passed extreme abortion legislation that would make late-term abortions much easier to obtain. Vermont is now working legislation that would go even farther. Its alarming. As a member of the Pro-Life Caucus, we will continue to call up this legislation in the House until we are given a vote. I wont stop standing up for the most innocent in our society. Protecting 2nd Amendment Rights This week, I voted against H.R. 8 and H.R. 1112, bills attempting to roll back Americans Second Amendment rights. The bills contained numerous problems and would do little to prevent criminals from accessing firearms. For instance, providing a gun as a gift to a cousin or an in-law would be illegal under this bill. Also, while there was a hunting exception included, its so vague that it may criminalize sportsmen and sportswomen that are simply handing a firearm to their hunting partner. Weve previously passed legislation to fix and strengthen the NICS background check system, provide more resources to schools to address gun violence, and reform the mental health system  all steps to enforce the current laws on the books and keep guns out of the hands of criminals. The two bills that passed the House this week would not have stopped recent shootings, but they would criminalize the law-abiding gun owners that I represent. I voted no on both pieces of legislation. Enjoy your week and please don't hesitate to reach out to my office if I or my staff can be of service to you. Sincerely, Congressman Bob Latta Unsubscribe:

body: Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email   /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin: 0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; }                                       Instagram  Flickr                       Dear Friend,  As Congress begins its new session, I want to share some of the highlights from the past year and get your input on what you want to see me working on in 2019. Over the past year, we’ve made progress on strengthening Virginia’s economy, combatting the opioid epidemic, and supporting our national defense. I’ve shared a partial list of some of the successes of the past year below.  While I’m proud of the progress we’ve made in the past year, I also recognize we’re facing some challenging times as a country. I’m writing you in the midst of a disastrous, pointless government shutdown that has thrown the lives of thousands of Virginians into chaos. I’ve set up a special page on my website with updates on my work to end the shutdown and resources for federal workers and contractors affected by it. I remain committed to ending this unnecessary shutdown and making sure the workers impacted by it are made whole.  But right now, I want to hear from you. What would you like to see me work on in the coming year? I’ve prepared a brief survey for you to share your thoughts, and I hope you’ll take a moment to let me know what’s on your mind.  I look forward to hearing from you.  Sincerely,        2018 Accomplishments The President signed into law several bills I sponsored or co-authored:   The Ashanti Alert Act, creating an alert system for missing adults. A bipartisan opioids package that included several bills I authored. Legislation granting federal recognition to six Virginia Indian tribes after hundreds of years An amendment to improve Black Lung screening for coal miners. The Forever GI Bill Housing Payment Fulfillment Act, to reimburse veterans for missed or underpaid housing benefits due to errors at the VA. A bill renaming a Charlottesville post office after the late Capt. Humayun Khan, who was killed in action in Iraq. Legislation reforming the Department of Defense's purchasing process for cybersecurity services. An expansion of the Petersburg National Battlefield. Bipartisan banking reform legislation to help small, community banks and credit unions compete and better serve their customers. A bipartisan Farm Bill that included legislation I sponsored to legalize industrial hemp.  That legislation also included a bill I cosponsored to aid domestic violence survivors and their family pets.   Bipartisan legislation improving care for Medicare patients with chronic medical conditions.  As Vice Chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee:   Passed crucial re-authorization legislation through the committee supporting the intelligence community and improving Congressional oversight. Introduced legislation to reform our nation’s broken security clearance system. Developed policy proposals to protect Americans and their private data from foreign adversaries and other bad actors on social media. Investigated Russia’s attempts to undermine our democracy, and uncovered new evidence of Russian attempts to target African-American voters and other communities with misinformation and disinformation. Led the call for the establishment of a U.S. Cyber Doctrine.  Working with Senator Kaine, we had success on a number of Virginia priorities, including:   New investments in military readiness, including $131 million for base construction expenses, new funding for naval shipbuilding, and a raise for the troops. Increased funding for job training programs, rural broadband, college affordability, and Chesapeake Bay cleanup, among other priorities. Water infrastructure legislation that invests in the Port of Virginia and flood-resilience programs. More than $210,000,000 in federal grant funding for Virginia announced by our offices.                          703 Hart Senate Office Building. Washington, D.C. 20510 Tel: (202) 224-2023  PREPARED, PUBLISHED, AND MAILED AT TAXPAYER EXPENSE

body: Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email   /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin: 0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; }    p { margin-bottom:1em }          News from Congressman Steve Cohen                               Website |  Serving You |  Legislative Work |  Our District |  Resources                January 11, 2019       Dear Friend,  This week, I voted on a series of spending bills to re-open parts of the federal government shuttered by the Trump shutdown. I also expressed disappointment at President Trump’s misleading address to the nation on the U.S.-Mexico border situation, co-sponsored a bill that would require universal background checks for gun purchases, voted to authorize the House to intervene in a federal lawsuit in a Texas case involving the Affordable Care Act, congratulated three new Memphis City Council members, wrote about my Constitutional amendment to eliminate the Electoral College, attended an event honoring former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords and the late Congressman Leo Ryan, offered 2019 Capitol Historical Society calendars and suggested a health tip for preventing sickness in pets. Keep reading to learn more about my week and follow me on Twitter and Facebook to see more updates as they happen.  Voting to Re-open Departments Closed by Trump Shutdown  Reacting to Trump’s Border Wall “Crisis” Speech  Attending Event Honoring Gabby Giffords and the late Leo Ryan  Co-Sponsoring Bipartisan Background Checks Act of 2019  Authorizing the House to Intervene in Appeal of Texas ACA Case  Congratulating New City Council Members Greer, Johnson and Currie  Writing Opinion Article on Ending the Electoral College  Holding a District Issues Meeting on Friday  Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars   Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter   Weekly Health Tip  Quote of the Week     Voting to Re-open Departments Closed by Trump Shutdown  This week, the House took up and passed a series of bills -- drafted by Senate Republicans and passed overwhelmingly by the Senate last year -- in an effort to re-open the government and put federal workers back to work. See my releases on the subject here and here and here. As I write this, an intransigent Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is refusing to bring the measures to the Senate floor for a vote, and the Trump shutdown continues. The costs of the shutdown are already extending beyond those directly affected and will pose increasing risks to the U.S. economy. Business confidence may weaken; consumer spending may slow; travel delays are starting to be seen at some airports; mortgage processing is threatened and the broader economy may be slowing.  Reacting to Trump’s Border Wall “Crisis” Speech  I watched President Trump’s first address to the nation from the Oval Office and was disappointed to hear the same misleading fearmongering and simplistic commentary. See my statement on the speech here.  Attending Event Honoring Gabby Giffords and the late Leo Ryan    On Wednesday, I attended the unveiling of a plaque naming the House Democratic Cloakroom in the U.S. Capitol for former Arizona Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords and the late California Congressman Leo J. Ryan. Gabby was in my 2006 Congressional class and I was deeply troubled by the attack on her and her staff in January 2011 from which she is still recovering. Gabby is an active proponent for sensible gun policy and continues to advance good causes despite her continuing physical challenges. Ryan was a fighter for justice whose 1978 in-person fact-finding mission to the Peoples Temple cult in Johnstown, Guyana, led to his assassination. Ryan’s staffer Jackie Speier was seriously wounded in the incident but is now Congresswoman Speier after succeeding my friend and hero, the late Tom Lantos, in representing part of the Bay Area. As Speaker Nancy Pelosi said in unveiling the Giffords-Ryan plaque, “We inscribe their names in the halls of Congress as an enduring monument to their legacies of heroism and selflessness.”     Co-Sponsoring Bipartisan Background Checks Act of 2019  Gun violence prevention is a high priority for the new Majority and I was pleased to join Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler, Gun Violence Prevention Task Force Chairman Mike Thompson and others on Tuesday in co-sponsoring a major initiative. The Bipartisan Background Checks Act of 2019 (H.R. 8) would require background checks on all gun sales. Gabby Giffords, as a former member, was on the House floor when the bill was introduced.  Authorizing the House to Intervene in Appeal of Texas ACA Case  On Tuesday, I voted to authorize the House to intervene in the federal court case out of Texas in which a judge recently declared the Affordable Care Act (ACA) unconstitutional. The ACA provides affordable health insurance coverage to over 20 million people and ensures that insurers can no longer refuse coverage to Americans with pre-existing conditions. I will continue to fight to see that protection preserved.   Congratulating New City Council Members Greer, Johnson and Currie    I send my congratulations to Southwest Tennessee Community College Administrator Sherman Greer, former Shelby County Assessor Cheyenne Johnson and Whitehaven Community Development Officer Gerre Currie for their appointments to the Memphis City Council this week. Sherman Greer was my first District Director and always put helping constituents first; Cheyenne Johnson has been a good friend for 40 years; and Gerre Currie is held in high esteem. It’s good to see the Council back to its full 13-member strength.  Writing Opinion Article on Ending the Electoral College  This Sunday, The Commercial Appeal will run an opinion article I wrote about a Constitutional amendment I introduced to eliminate the Electoral College, an institution that has resulted in five presidents taking office despite losing the popular vote. See my article here. (An online version was published Thursday.)  Holding a District Issues Meeting on Friday Please join me at the District Issues Meeting at my Memphis office on Friday, January 18, to talk about what matters to you and your family. As always, I will share with you the work I’m doing on behalf of the 9th Congressional District. My staff and I look forward to seeing you.  When: Friday, January 19, 2019, 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. Where: Clifford Davis/Odell Horton Federal Building, 167 North Main Street, Suite 369, Memphis  Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars          My office has a limited number of 2019 U.S. Capitol Historical Society calendars available. If you would like to receive a calendar, please complete this form on my website. Due to the rules of the House, I can mail calendars only to residents of Tennessee’s 9th Congressional District. Please feel free to share this email with other residents of the 9th District who may be interested in receiving one but who do not receive my e-Newsletter.    Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter     I enjoy meeting regularly with constituents in the district and helping provide answers to questions about dealing with federal agencies. If you are interested in attending one of my “Congress on Your Corner” events, you can sign up here to receive notification as soon as the next event is scheduled.    For those who haven’t participated in a telephone town hall, it’s easy to sign up for them by using this form.      If you would like to receive this weekly e-Newsletter, or share it with others, you can do that with this form.    Weekly Health Tip    As animal lover, and supporter of animal welfare issues, I’m aware that attention to pet diets and other pet needs helps keep them, and their owners, healthy. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has useful information on keeping pets healthy here.  Quote of the Week   “The shutdown is harming the American people, the business community, and the economy. The adverse consequences of the shutdown are wide and growing.” – U.S. Chamber of Commerce executive vice president Neil Bradley, January 8, 2019.  As always, I remain, Most Sincerely,    Steve Cohen Member of Congress                           Memphis  167 North Main Street, Suite 369 Memphis, TN 38103 Phone: (901) 544-4131 Fax: (901) 544-4329  Washington, D.C.  2104 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-3265 Fax: (202) 225-5663                      Private Policy

name: Rep. Jackie Speier
subject: Legislative Update and Priorities for the 116th Congress
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin: 0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; }      News from Representative Speier  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email                                                                    January 8, 2019     Dear Friends,  As we embark on a new year, I thought you might want an update on my legislative accomplishments in the 115th Congress and a look at my priorities for the 116th Congress and the next two years.     Legislative Update   Congress Passes Bipartisan Anti-Sexual Harassment Legislation    Last month, Congress passed the comprehensive Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 Reform Act, based on my ME TOO Congress Act. Members of Congress will now be held personally liable for all forms of harassment, including sexual harassment, and retaliation. And survivors will no longer be hindered by an obstacle-ridden dispute resolution process that had been stacked in favor of perpetrators and the institution in their pursuit of justice.  Ratifying the ERA – Only One State Away!   To give women and girls the legal standing needed to fight harassment and discrimination at school, in the workplace, and in the military, we must pass my resolution to remove the deadline and allow for the ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) to the U.S. Constitution. With both Nevada’s and Illinois’s ratification of the ERA in 2017 and 2018 respectively, we are now just one state shy of achieving gender equality.  Alleviating Airport Noise   Airplane noise has become an ever-increasing concern in our communities due to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)’s implementation of the NextGen navigation program. The FAA Reauthorization Act, which passed in October 2018, included my provisions to require the FAA to undertake several new studies to research the economic and health impacts of airplane noise and new methods for alleviating airplane noise.   Fighting for Local Fishermen  I introduced H.R. 2344, the Crab Emergency Disaster Assistance Act, to assist the commercial fishermen and local businesses that were economically devastated by the closure of the Dungeness crab season in 2016 due to a toxic algae bloom. The bill would provide $117 million in critically-needed disaster relief funds to help these hard-working men and woman stay in business.  Stopping Incessant Robocalls  Although the FCC Chairman recently demanded that the phone industry adopt a call authentication system to combat illegal caller ID spoofing by next year, much more must be done to address the scourge of robocalls that result in over $350 million lost to phone scams each year. That is why I introduced H.R. 5573, the ROBOCOP (Repeated Objectionable Bothering of Consumers on Phones) Act, to require phone companies to provide customers with free tools to block robocalls.  Standing Against Family Separation    I led a delegation of my Democratic colleagues to visit Department of Homeland Security (DHS) immigration facilities and a Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) child shelter in South Texas in June of 2018 to see firsthand the impact of the Trump Administration’s cruel “zero tolerance” policy. I also called on DHS and HHS to address my concerns, demanded greater transparency about the treatment of detained families, and demanded that the Administration immediately reunite children who remain separated from their families.    Supporting Our Troops at The Border   I traveled to our southern border at Christmastime to visit troops deployed to Southern California by President Trump one week before the November elections. Sen. Elizabeth Warren and I sent a bicameral letter to Defense Secretary Jim Mattis expressing grave concerns over the highly suspicious timing of sending 5,000 active duty military personnel to the region, which was described by the Pentagon as “an expensive waste of time and resources, and a morale killer to boot.” We have also questioned the extent of the Department of Defense resources that have been expended on this operation.    Allowing Our Furry Friends in the GGNRA   In 2017, the Golden Gate National Recreation Area finally dropped its flawed dog management plan, allowing dog owners to walk their pets off-leash as they have for decades. Next up, establishing an off-leash dog area in San Mateo County which has none.  Protecting Students from Sexual Harassment & Violence  Over the past two years, President Trump and Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos have led a campaign to roll back Title IX protections and force survivors of sexual violence in schools and on college campuses back into the shadows. I have introduced H.R. 4030, the Title IX Protection Act, which codifies Obama-era Title IX guidance. I also introduced and H.R. 6464, the HALT Act, which goes beyond Title IX protections to strengthen prevention and enforcement efforts designed to combat campus sexual violence. I also led several letters to Secretary DeVos, the most recent of which urged her to abandon her dangerous proposal and instead meet with a broad range of survivor advocacy organizations to develop meaningful guidance to protect all students.  Protecting Transgender Servicemembers   President Trump announced his bigoted policy to ban new transgendered servicemembers in July 2017, with it taking effect in early 2018 and leaving many of our current servicemembers in limbo. In response to his attack on our brave troops, I introduced a bipartisan bill (H.R. 4041) to protect transgender members of the U.S. military by preventing the Department of Defense (DoD) from removing any currently serving members of the Armed Forces based solely on gender identity.  Ending the Shipping Ban on Alcohol   I introduced the bipartisan USPS Shipping Equity Act to end the Prohibition-era ban against shipping or delivering alcoholic beverages in compliance with the buyer’s state law. This bill would give consumers another option besides private shippers – such as UPS and FedEx – and would bring in $50 million of new revenue for our struggling USPS.  Halting Law Enforcement Abuse of Power   about a teenage girl who was raped by two police officers while in their custody exposed a since-closed loophole in New York state law that allowed the officers to argue the sex was consensual. That glaring legal technicality still exists in federal law enforcement and in 30 other states, which is why I introduced H.R. 6568, the Closing the Law Enforcement Consent Loophole Act. My bill makes it a crime for federal officers to have sexual encounters with anyone in their custody or who is being held under the color of law and provides incentives to the 30 remaining states to pass similar laws.  Addressing “Revenge Porn” in the Military   After hearing from numerous servicewomen who were attacked via websites and online groups like Marines United, which obtain and post obscene and abusive pictures, I was appalled to learn that the distribution of intimate photos without one’s consent was not clearly defined as illegal under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. To address this injustice I introduced H.R. 2050 – the PRIVATE Act – which became law in December 2017, and explicitly prohibits the sharing of intimate images without consent.  Constituent Outreach  Town Hall Meetings   Over the last two years I have held 16 town halls throughout the 14th Congressional District. These meetings are invaluable for me to learn about your concerns and ideas. They also inspire me to keep fighting for your rights, protections, and freedoms in Washington, DC. Attendance has ranged from approximately 200 to 1,900 attendees – the latter of which was both the largest town hall in my district and one of, if not THE largest in the country. I know the last two years have been trying, but your participation and passion has been crucial to our successes in the past Congress. I urge and encourage you to stay engaged and active. I will continue to hold town halls in 2019 and look forward to seeing you there.  Mail  Constituent outreach is an essential part of my job. I am grateful to represent a district filled with passionate people who are willing to share their thoughts on the issues that matter most. Over the course of the 115th Congress, my offices logged almost 125,000 letters, e-mails, phone calls, and faxes from constituents. I personally reviewed these logs and approved and signed every response. And I rely on the opinions and insights you share with me when weighing policy and other strategic decisions, so I look forward to hearing more from you in the 116th Congress!  ---  It’s my greatest privilege to serve as your Member of Congress and I look forward to continuing that service in the Democratically-controlled House of Representatives. Last year ended with a historic Pink Wave with the most women, including the most women of color, elected to serve in Congress. And I will work with the women and men of the 116th Congress to build on this incredible opportunity to advance progressive policies that benefit all Americans.  We have more work to do to hold the President and his Administration accountable for their incompetence and corruption, which is why I am introducing legislation to reform our ethics and campaign finance laws and promote greater transparency by requiring every candidate for the Office of President and Vice President to provide tax returns for the last 10 years to the public.  In my roles on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence and the House Armed Services Committee, I will continue to monitor the Russia investigation, make sure our servicemembers and their families have the support they need, and work to weed out waste, fraud, abuse.  I will also do everything I can to ensure that everyone has a fair shot at the American dream and that we can all give our children a better life by protecting the ACA and those with preexisting conditions, lowering drug prices, increasing access to health care, strengthening our nation's woefully inadequate gun safety laws, creating greater economic opportunities through the improvement of our nation’s infrastructure, and fixing our broken immigration system.  Finally, I will continue to champion women’s equality, LGBTQ rights, and the rights of the disenfranchised by taking my fight to eliminate harassment and discrimination in Congress to our schools, workplaces, and the military. That includes pushing for the passage of the Equal Rights Amendment to the U.S. Constitution – this is the year that we will finally declare victory!  I hope that the new year is filled with happiness, health, and success for you and your loved ones, and our country. It truly is an honor to represent you and I promise to continue my work to strengthen our democracy and secure a safe and prosperous future for generations to come.  All the best,                                                       Washington, DC  2465 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-3531 Fax: (202) 226-4183  San Mateo Office  155 Bovet Road, Suite 780 San Mateo, CA 94402  Phone: (650) 342-0300 Fax: (650) 375-8270             Privacy Policy     p { margin-bottom:1em; }
