subject: Working for PA-10
body: Congressman Tom Marino, Proudly Representing the 10th District of Pennsylvania *Working for PA-10* *From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:* Good morning, This week in the House, I voted for programs critical to our communities, discouraged sexual harassment in the workplace and kept our nation safe and free. I also introduced legislation to protect animals and recognized PA-10 athletes competing in the Winter Olympics in South Korea. Here are some of the highlights of my work in Washington on behalf of Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District: *Funding our Nation's Priorities* I was pleased to join my House colleagues to pass the *Bipartisan Budget Act [link 1] *which keeps the federal government open and increases funding for America's military. This legislation includes numerous programs [link 2] that are a priority to PA-10 and ensures our brave troops get the resources they need to protect our freedoms. Many of my constituents rely on the services provided by Community Health Centers [link 3] and Teaching Health Centers [link 4] to enhance their quality of life. This measure also repeals Obamacare's onerous Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB). *Fostering a Safe Work Environment* News of a secretive process [link 5] for settling sexual harassment complaints against members of Congress sent shockwaves across Capitol Hill. To address this unacceptable practice, the House passed two bipartisan measures [link 6] that promote greater accountability and transparency for the congressional workplace. Any form of sexual harassment is completely unacceptable. I recently introduced legislation to ensure taxpayers not foot the bill [link 7] for the misdeeds of federal lawmakers and to require repayment [link 8] of public funds used to settle those cases. *Protecting Animals* As an animal lover, it breaks my heart to see any animal suffer or die because they are left in a parked vehicle in extreme heat or cold. That is why I introduced the *Keep Our Pets Safe Act* [link 9]. This commonsense legislation makes it a federal offense to leave a pet in a car. if the animal could die as result of excessive exposure to heat or cold, lack of ventilation, or lack of water. I strongly urge my colleagues in the House to support this bill. *Looking out for Taxpayers* During income tax filing season there have been a growing number of cybercriminals who steal data from tax practitioners' computers and submit fraudulent returns requesting refunds with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) [link 10]. Cybercriminals have evolved their deceptive tactics to focus on tax professionals where they can steal client data. Should PA-10 tax professionals have any questions or concerns please feel free to contact [link 11] our Washington or District Offices. *PA-10 Goes for Gold* PA-10 has two athletes competng in the Winter Olympics. Congratulations to figure skater Adam Rippon [link 12] and luger Jayson Terdiman [link 13] who are going for the gold in PyeongChang, South Korea. Mr. Rippon, a native of Clarks Summit, qualified for his first Olympic team after being sidelined for five months due to injury. Two years ago, he was senior Men's national figure skating champion. Mr. Terdiman, who hails from Berwick, took part in the 2014 Sochi Olympcis and this year will compete in the Men's Doubles event. All of Pennsylvania is rooting for you and cheering you on from home! *As Always...* Please never hesitate to contact [link 14] me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C. I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way. For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook [link 15], Twitter [link 16] and Instagram [link 17]. body: Last week, I hosted a bipartisan BBQ lunch with my friend, Republican Senator Jeff Flake from Arizona, highlighting in a fun way our bipartisan bill to get rid of "pork-barrel" spending in Congress by permanently banning earmarks. And I personally attribute the event's success to some very special sauce... Earmarks are the swampiest of swamp creatures, and they're notorious for their secrecy and their lack of oversight and accountability. They allow politicians to award pet projects based on political influence instead of merit, and that's just hogwash. Taxpayer dollars shouldn't be doled out in secretno "ifs," "ands," or "pork butts" about it. Watch a few minutes of my bipartisan lunch with Senator Flake as we answer questions about our fight to permanently ban earmarks: Getting rid of earmarks has been an ongoing battle here in the Senate, and one I'm proud to keep fighting for alongside Senator Flake. Elected officials shouldn't need bribes to do the jobs they were elected to do. name: Senator Roger Wicker
subject: Artificial Intelligence: What It Means and Why It Matters
body: *Wicker Chairs Hearing on Artificial Intelligence* *Congress Explores Future of Machine Learning* What exactly is artificial intelligence, and what does it mean for how we live and work? That was the topic of discussion at a recent hearing I chaired on "Digital Decision-Making," held before the Senate subcommittee that oversees Internet and telecommunications issues. Artificial intelligence, often referred to as AI, might sound straight out of a science fiction book or TV show, but it is becoming an increasingly common, if not instrumental, part of everyday life. AI is the technology that enables a machine to make a decision based on the data it has collected, such as when a smartphone gives driving directions around congested traffic or an e-mail system detects spam messages. Social media, online shopping, and preventing credit card fraud all have AI components. The applications are widespread, and the technology is evolving swiftly, creating a need for conversations to ensure it is being used safely and responsibly. The experts who testified at the hearing detailed how AI is being harnessed to improve ways farmers grow crops, doctors treat illnesses, manufacturers produce goods, and teachers give feedback to students. There are revolutionary, headline-grabbing AI breakthroughs such as self-driving cars, but there are also much more subtle public and private sector advancements in AI that are working to cut costs, boost productivity, and create better lives for Americans. *MSU Working on Robots for Law Enforcement, Therapy* A lot of that work is being done in Mississippi. One of the hearing's witnesses was Dr. Cindy L. Bethel, an associate professor of computer science and engineering at Mississippi State University. In her testimony, she noted three specific AI projects at the university. One is using AI research for robots that could help law enforcement respond to dangerous situations. The robots would collect information about the crime scene before officers have to put themselves in harm's way. Another project is focusing on an autonomous transport system for cargo, and a third is developing a robotic therapy dog, which could be used by those who are allergic to pets. Likewise, for the past two years, the University of Mississippi has held a Tech Summit to engage students, faculty, industry experts, business executives, and policymakers on the future of technology in our state and nation. The forum reaffirms Mississippi's reputation as a place for innovation and illustrates the commitment of our universities to help lead the way. *Software Industry Delivers Jobs, Economic Benefits in Miss.* Advancements in AI could have a major impact on the careers available to tomorrow's workforce. I am a strong advocate of STEM education and authored a bill earlier this year to promote computer science programs. The field is ripe for young talent, with the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics expecting 1.3 million job openings in computing by 2022. During the subcommittee hearing, Victoria Espinel, chief executive officer of The Software Alliance, noted that the software industry supports 7,000 jobs and generates more than $800 million in Mississippi. This is an exciting time for our state, and I look forward to seeing how AI can continue to transform our communities in positive ways. The possibilities are truly limitless. *Other news this week:* - Wicker Proposal for 355 Ships Signed Into Law [link 1] - Wicker Announces Safety Update for Navy Training Jets [link 2] - Senators Support Block Buy of Future Aircraft Carriers [link 3] - Wicker, Hassan Introduce Internet of Things Consumer TIPS Act [link 4] - Wicker Responds to FCC Vote on Open Internet [link 5] - Wicker Convenes Hearing on Artificial Intelligence Technologies [link 6] - Wicker Receives Aircraft Owners & Pilots Association Award [link 7] - Wicker, Cardin Name Kyle Parker to Lead U.S. Helsinki Commission Staff [link 8] *Fox & Friends First Highlights Progress on T-45 Training Jet Safety Issues [link 9]* * [image = [link 10]* Watch as Fox & Friends First reports on Senator Wicker's efforts to expedite a solution to recent safety issues with the Navy's T-45 training jets, which are based in Meridian. *Wicker Supports Block Buy of 2 Gerald R. name: Senator Jon Tester
subject: Can you tell me what this word is?
body: Dear Lindsey, Washington is broken. There is no doubt about it. Last week, I was handed a 479-page tax bill just hours before it was scheduled for a final vote. A small group of senators wrote this disastrous scheme behind closed doors with no input from the public, and they gave nobody time to read it. The bill included last-minute additions scribbled in the margins that nobody could read. As we began voting on amendments, folks were finding secret pet projects and sweetheart deals that were snuck into the bill at the very last minute. That was Washington at its worst. Our nations founders must have been turning in their graves. My job is to hold Washington accountable to Montana. Thats why on the Senate Banking Committee, I am working closely with Republicans, Democrats, and Independents to rise above the dysfunction. After months of negotiations with folks from both parties, we struck a deal on a major bill that delivers much-needed relief to Montana from Washingtons one-size-fits-all regulations. Our bipartisan legislation will cut red tape for small community banks and credit unions and it increase access to capital for local businesses, farmers and ranchers, and families. It also strengthens consumer protections against Wall Street. Our bill is bringing folks from all walks of life and political parties together, and it is forging a new path of bipartisanship in the Senate. On Tuesday, we held a committee meeting to discuss and make changes to the bill, which lasted over 6 hours. That is how it is supposed to work in Washington: open, fair debate in the light of dayon a bill everyone is allowed to discuss. Our process drafting this bill has been transparent and our bill is posted online HERE for all to see. None of that was true about the unpopular tax reform bill that will add another $1.5 trillion to the national debt. Last week, we saw how partisan Washington can be. But when folks put politics aside and work towards a common goal, we can break through the dysfunction and do whats best for the country. TESTER.SENATE.GOV | UNSUBSCRIBE

body: .       Discussing the news from the Treasury during a press conference with my colleague, Rep. John Larson of Connecticut           Helping our Neighbors This week I stopped by the Enfield Food Shelf to see first-hand the work that local volunteers are doing to help friends and neighbors in the community. There, I helped hand out turkeys and met with some volunteers. Over the last few days, they’ve seen hundreds of people come for some extra help this Thanksgiving for their families, and even their pets. Thank you to all those in Enfield -- and communities across eastern Connecticut -- who are helping to make this holiday a little brighter for their neighbors.       Handing out turkeys with volunteers at the Enfield Food Shelf      Meeting the New Navy Secretary I recently met with our newest Navy Secretary, Richard V. Spencer. Secretary Spencer is a Connecticut native with long ties to our region -- his father worked at Electric Boat in the 1940s. Although we have spoken by phone a few times since he was confirmed, this was our first chance to talk face-to-face and discuss the challenges facing our Navy. In our meeting, we talked about a range of issues that we are grappling with on the Seapower subcommittee -- expanding the Navy surface and undersea fleet, increasing capabilities of our ships and following through on the changes needed in light of the ship collisions earlier this year. I appreciated his candor and willingness to engage with me as ranking member of the subcommittee, and look forward to working with him. I also invited Secretary Spencer to come visit eastern Connecticut to see firsthand the outstanding work that our sailors at Submarine Base New London, as well as the talented workforce at Electric Boat, do every single day to support our Navy. He committed to visiting, and I hope he can make it up soon!         Meeting with Navy Secretary Spencer in my Washington, D.C. office          Blue Ribbon Honors for Eastern Connecticut Schools In September, our region got the good news that three schools in eastern Connecticut were recognized as Blue Ribbon schools by the federal Department of Education: East Lyme High School, Thomas W. Mahan Elementary School in Norwich, and the Oakdale Elementary School in Montville. This award, granted by the United States Department of Education, honors schools demonstrating high achievement. These schools were three of the five honored from Connecticut this year, and among the the 342 across the country to receive the Blue Ribbon. Unfortunately, the team at Mahan Elementary in Norwich did not have the budget to send anyone to Washington to receive their award -- so I stopped by this week to present it to them.  During my visit, I visited classrooms and got some great questions from the students. More importantly I got to see firsthand the work that had earned the school this well-deserved recognition. Congratulations to all of those that have worked so hard to ensure that our children receive the best education possible. Well done!       Celebrating the Blue Ribbon designation at Mahan Elementary in Norwich       Thank you, as always, for reading this update. I wish you and your family a very happy Thanksgiving. name: Congressman Buddy Carter
subject: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act
body: THE TAX CUTS AND JOBS ACT This week, House Republicans introduced the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the House Republicans tax relief plan. This legislation will finally deliver relief from America's antiquated and overly burdensome tax code which I believe is the greatest threat to economic opportunity in this country. Most importantly, this plan will give middle-class American families, on average, a $1,182 tax cut. I have been asking families across the First District what they would do with the hard-earned dollars our plan would let Americans keep from their paychecks. They told me they will help their families, give back to their communities, or invest in their businesses and create jobs. This plan will empower all Americans to achieve the American Dream and I am excited to work with my colleagues to finalize the largest reform of our tax code in more than thirty years. Among other tax relief measures, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act: Lowers individual tax rates for low- and middle- income Americans to Zero, 12%, 25%, and 35% while continuing to maintain 39.6% for high-income Americans; Significantly increases the standard deduction from $6,350 to $12,000 for individuals and $12,700 to $24,000 for married couples; Eliminates special-interest deductions; Establishes a new Family Credit, which includes expanding the Child Tax Credit from $1,000 to $1,600; Preserves the Earned Income Tax Credit and the home mortgage interest deduction for existing mortgages and maintains the home mortgage deduction for newly purchased homes up to $500,000; Lowers the corporate rate to 20%, down from 35%; and, Reduces the tax rate on small business to no more than 25% - the lowest tax rate on small business income since World War II. To learn more about the legislation or to read it for yourself, click here. THE CHILDREN'S HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM This week, the House passed the CHAMPIONING HEALTHY KIDS Act with my support. The legislation extends the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) for five years. I am glad this legislation passed the House this week, but we're over a month late in reauthorizing the program while the families of 9 million children are holding their breath to see whether their kids are going to have health insurance. The reason we are so delayed is because my colleagues on the other side of the aisle asked us to delay, and in good faith, we did. My colleagues on the other side of the aisle decided to delay our efforts to pass the bill out of the Energy and Commerce Committee and they decided to delay bringing the bill to the floor for a vote. I would hope they have a good reason for these delaying tactics, but the truth is that they opposed a provision requested by President Obama in his fiscal year 2013 - fiscal year 2017 budgets that has a minor impact on the highest earners under Medicare. This is politics at its worst. I hope the Senate will act swiftly on this legislation. The more than 232,000 children in Georgia who rely on CHIP for their health insurance are depending on it. FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CXXXVIII Monday, October 30, 2017: I wake up this morning in Bridgewater, New Jersey, after having flown here yesterday from Savannah. Im here to visit with Sanofi, a worldwide leader in pharmaceutical manufacturing and life sciences. As a pharmacist, I am very familiar with the company as I have dispensed many of their products throughout my professional career. My first meeting is with the executive leadership team as they bring me up to date with issues impacting their business and challenges they face in the health care marketplace. Afterwards, I have the honor of addressing their employees to bring them up to date on Washington issues, particularly health care, and participate in a question and answer session. Next, I head to Swedesboro, New Jersey, where I tour Wedgewood Pharmacy, one of the largest compounding pharmacies in the United States. Although they serve the human health market, their main emphasis is the veterinary market where they have made over 7,500 different preparations for companion animals like dogs, cats, birds and horses as well as some less common like hippopotamuses and reptiles. During my visit I asked one of the pharmacists what was the most unusual animal for which she had ever prepared a medication. Her response was that they once filled a prescription for a pet dolphin! I forgot to ask if its name was Flipper. Afterwards, I head to Philadelphia where I take a flight to Atlanta to attend the Georgia Republican Partys Annual Chairmans Dinner with guest speaker Dr. Ben Carson, U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Rep. Carter with Reps. Belton (R-Buckhead) and Corbett (R-Lake Park)Tuesday, October 31, 2017: After an early morning meeting in downtown Atlanta with members of the Georgia Bankers Association, I head up I-75 to Marietta where I have a tour of Dow Chemical to learn more of their work in the state of Georgia. Afterwards, I head to Hartsfield-Jackson Airport for my flight back to Washington and on the way have a phone interview with WTOC in Savannah to discuss national issues. Once back in my office in Washington, I have a call with a constituent to discuss the upcoming tax reform legislation before we have our weekly staff briefing. Afterwards, I head to a messaging advisory group meeting with Republican Conference Chair Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-WA) before heading to our weekly Whip Team meeting where we discuss the upcoming week that will include the rollout of the long awaited tax reform legislation. My last commitment of the day is in the House Chamber as we have our first vote series of the week. Wednesday, November 1, 2017: After a series of office meetings this morning, including a lengthy meeting with my legislative staff to review and plan for legislation that I will be working on in the near future, I head to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the day. Next, I have a meeting with representatives from the American College of Surgeons followed by a phone interview with Breitbart News to discuss legislation I am sponsoring that will reform parts of the Medicaid program. After filming a video in my office detailing the tax reform legislation that we will be rolling out tomorrow, I head to the House Visitors Center where I am presented an award by Healthy Families Georgia for my work in supporting their organization. Afterwards, I head to the House Chamber where we have our second and final vote series of the day. Rep. Carter at a meeting of the Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee discussing the Federal Select Agent Program oversight of dangerous pathogens Thursday, November 2, 2017: Im back in the House Visitors Center this morning as my fellow Georgia delegation members and I meet with a group of Georgia State Representatives serving on a military study committee to discuss how we can further support the missions of Georgias military installations and personnel. This group, led by Rep. Dave Belton (R-Buckhead), includes First District Representatives Al Williams (D-Hinesville) and John Corbett (R-Lake Park). Afterwards, I head to a meeting with representatives from the Georgia Psychiatric Physician Association where we have a very productive discussion regarding the opioid epidemic. My next meeting is our weekly GOP member conference which was postponed for a day so that the Ways and Means Committee could finish their work on the tax reform legislation that is being rolled out today. Todays meeting is longer than usual as we have an extended open mic session to allow members to voice their opinions on the legislation, which is overwhelmingly positive. Afterwards, I head to a meeting of the Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee where we have a hearing on concerns over the Federal Select Agent Program Oversight of Dangerous Pathogens. Rep. Carter speaks in support of the Children's Health Insurance Program A link to my questions can be found here. Later, I head to the House Chamber where I speak during debate of legislation to eliminate the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB). A link to my speech can be found here. Next, I stay in the House Chamber and speak on the next bill being debated, the Childrens Health Insurance Program (CHIP). A link to my comments on this bill can be found here. Our first vote series of the day is next and during this vote we have the official picture of the 115th Congress taken. Once back in my office, I have a phone interview with WJCL TV in Savannah to discuss tax reform followed by a skype interview with WSAV TV on the same subject. Afterwards, I head back to the House Chamber for our second and final vote series of the day and then head back to my office for a meeting with the Charleston VA Medical Center Director, Scott Isaacks. Next, I attend our second GOP Members Conference of the day where we get more detailed information on the tax reform legislation. Friday, November 3, 2017: After early morning radio interviews with Scott James in Valdosta and Bill Edwards and Laura Anderson in Savannah to discuss tax reform, I head to the White House to assist constituents in gaining access.  Rep. Carter live on MSNBC Afterwards, I head to the Capitol Members Dining Room for a meeting of the Nuclear Security Working Group with Secretary of Energy Rick Perry. Next, I head to the House Chamber where I give a one minute speech on tax reform. A link to my speech can be found here. Afterwards, I stay in the House Chamber where I speak on the CHIP bill that is being voted on today. A link to my speech can be found here. After we vote on and pass the CHIP bill, I head to Statuary Hall where I have a live TV interview with MSNBC on tax reform. A link to my interview can be found here. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin: 0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; }                                    Home  About Ken  About Our District  News  Contact                                                       Weekly Newsletter  Dear Friend, I've had a busy October, but I wanted to take a chance to update you on what's happening in Washington. Protecting America's Energy Infrastructure I led a bi-partisan letter, signed by 84 of my colleagues, asking Attorney General Jeff Sessions about the Department of Justice's efforts to prosecute individuals who engage in criminal activity against our energy infrastructure. Environmental extremists have been open about their intentions to damage energy infrastructure and to harm the individuals who work in that industry. I will always support Americans' First Amendment right to protest. But destruction of property and violence against individuals are both illegal and potentially fatal. The Americans who live around and rely daily on this infrastructure deserve the opportunity to feel safe in their homes.  Restoring Article I Powers to Congress  I voted for H.R. 469, legislation that shores up legislative branch power in a few ways. It gives job creators and state regulators the ability to participate in the process of creating new regulations, so that the Judicial Branch alone is not crafting new regulations through litigation proceedings. It requires the Treasury Department to be more transparent about the ways in which Judgement Fund dollars are dispensed, ensuring court judgements and settlements don't end up in the hands of state sponsors of terror. And it improves the process for Congress to intervene in court cases that bring into question the constitutional powers of the Legislative Branch.        H.R. 469 helps to reassert the Constitutional powers of Congress.    Stop Settlement Slush Funds Act    I voted for the Stop Settlement Slush Funds Act, important legislation that ends a practice of the previous administration where, in my opinion, the Department of Justice required donations to liberal, third-party, outside groups as part of settlement agreements, basically using these settlements to fund its pet political causes instead of returning those dollars to actual lawsuit victims or the taxpayer. No DOJ should ever have the opportunity to use settlements for political gain. I’m thankful Attorney General Sessions has ended this practice. H.R. 732 allows us to permanently abolish this practice. Simple and Fair Tax Reform The House will soon release its tax reform plan. I'm eager to review the package and offer feedback on behalf of 4th Congressional District voters. If you have thoughts about tax reform, please don't hesitate to reach out to my office to share them with me. You can visit my website to send an email or you can call my office. No matter what, I will be fighting for a tax code that is both simple and fair. Letter on Amazon's Second Headquarters to Colorado I joined the rest of the Colorado U.S. House delegation in encouraging Amazon to locate their second headquarters, coming with 50,000 jobs, in our state. Our state has much to offer, and the letter provided a chance for us to promote Colorado's incredible living environment. Our outdoor recreation opportunities, strong education system, dynamic employers, moderate cost of living, wealth of energy sources, and strong transportation infrastructure all incentivize employers to locate their businesses in this beautiful state.  Helping Veterans Back in Colorado, I had the opportunity to sit down with several veterans who have struggled to receive the care they need from an overly bureaucratic, poorly managed Veterans Affairs Administration. Many of their stories were simply heartbreaking. These individuals paid a cost to defend our nation, and now they barely receive the healthcare they need. My office is working hard to resolve their individual cases, but I'm also pushing in Congress for reforms that  provide better care and greater choice for all our heroes.       I met with veterans who have faced red tape and poor care through the Veterans Affairs Administration.      As always, for more frequent updates on legislation and events, please follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. I look forward to hearing from you; please do not hesitate to contact my Greeley, Castle Rock, or Washington office should you need any assistance. If you'd like to send me a message, you can do so on my website. Sincerely,  Member of Congress      Subscribe for  Newsletter Updates Join me on... body: [cid:image001.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] Snow in Detroit Lakes this morning Dear Friends, The ongoing opioid crisis in our country has devastated families and rural communities and it is past time for strong action to be taken to keep our communities safe and healthy. This week, I worked to call attention to the continuing need for solutions to combat drug abuse. I joined Senator Klobuchar at a roundtable discussion in Thief River Falls last Friday to hear from local health professionals on treatment programs, and talked to Joel Heitkamp on KFGO News and Views Thursday morning to talk about effective policies that combat addiction. This issue will continue to grow unless we work together to find long-term solutions. You can read more about the issue in my letter-to-the-editor that was sent to local newspapers around the Seventh. Sincerely, [cid:image002.png@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] Congressman Collin C. Peterson Minnesota 7th District Opioid Roundtable [cid:image003.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] Senator Klobuchar and I heard from multiple state and local agencies as well as healthcare and treatment providers this week at our joint opioid roundtable. Opioid abuse continues to be a large-scale problem in our communities, and I am committed to finding workable solutions to combat this issue. National Sheriffs' Association [cid:image004.png@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] John Thompson, Deputy Executive Director On Tuesday, I met with John Thompson of the National Sheriffs' Association and discussed the importance of allowing domestic violence victims to bring their pets with them to shelters. Pets are members of the family and can provide great comfort to domestic violence victims. Currently, most shelters do not have the resources to house pets, but I fully support legislation that would give shelters access to grants to build pet amenities. Minnesota Telecom Alliance [cid:image005.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] This week, the Minnesota Telecom Alliance (MTA) visited my office to thank me for leading a letter urging the FCC to address the budget shortfall in the High-Cost Universal Service Fund (USF). A lack of sufficient funding for rural broadband development continues to put millions of Americans at a significant disadvantage. I appreciate the perspective of MTA as Congress works to connect rural residents, businesses, producers, and providers to each other and the world. Farm and Community Listening Sessions [cid:image006.png@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] Senator Klobuchar and I were pleased to join many farm commodity groups in Red Lake Falls for a listening session hosted by the wheat and barley growers. We addressed a wide range of questions, from the status of the next Farm Bill, to individual programs. Representing the needs of my constituents remains my top priority, and I'm appreciative of all who came out to talk about how we can best support our farmers and growers. Radio Interview with KFGO [cid:image007.png@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] I was a guest on KFGO News and Views with Joel Heitkamp on Thursday morning to talk about how the United States is facing an unprecedented opioid epidemic. It is critical that Congress develops effective policy to combat addiction. The opioid epidemic needs our immediate attention, and I am committed to ensuring that the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and Department of Justice are equipped to fight it. You can listen to our discussion online here. Felling Trailers [cid:image008.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] My staff met with members of the National Association of Trailer Manufacturers (NATM) this week. Pat Joenniseen of Felling Trailers in Sauk Centre highlighted the recurring challenges of finding and hiring skilled workers. In order for our businesses to expand, they need assurance that there will be skilled workers to hire. This is a common fear I hear from business owners in Minnesota. Being that this is a problem fairly unique to Minnesota, we should first look for a solution at the local level. A coordinated effort by the state, schools, unions, and businesses will be required in order to solve our shortage of skilled workers. I look forward to continuing conversations on supporting our local businesses. Cooperative Health Plan for Farmers [cid:image009.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] This week, my staff was briefed on a new Cooperative Health Plan for Farmers by 40 Square Cooperative Solutions. 40 Square is a cooperative dedicated to providing health plan options owned and governed by Minnesota farm families and the agricultural community. You can learn more on their website. Minnesota Department of Human Services [cid:image010.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] My staff attended Department of Human Services "Connections: Community Listening Event" discussing the needs in the community in the area of Mental Health, Housing, and Addictions. Information gathered at these sessions with help determine future efforts to supporter healthier communities. United Way of Southwest Minnesota [cid:image011.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] My staff aide, Meg Louwagie, participated in the United Way of Southwest Minnesota's joint effort with Jumpstart's "Read for the Record" nationwide campaign. The campaign aims to draw attention to the importance of early literacy by mobilizing adults and children to set a record for the largest shared reading experience. You can learn more online here. [cid:image012.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80]Legislative Update This week, the House passed two pieces of legislation targeted at increasing transparency in federal government settlements and to stop the "sue and settle" process of agency activism. One of these included the Stop Settlement Slush Funds Act of 2017, which I was the lead Democratic sponsor. The legislation seeks to stop the practice of the DOJ requiring donations to be directed towards certain groups, often politically motivated, as part of settlements. Finally, the House passed the Senate's budget, which I voted against. This budget will increase the debt by over $1.5 trillion, and I cannot support a bill so financially irresponsible. [cid:image013.gif@01D34F3F.05ABDE80]Newsstand National FFA Convention The 90th National FFA Convention will be held in Indianapolis this week. More than 64,000 FFA members from across the country are expected to attend the event. The National FFA Organization has record membership numbers this year, with 653,359 FFA members, more than 8,500 FFA chapters and more than 344,000 FFA Alumni members and 2,051 FFA alumni chapters across the country. Child Care Provider Grants Available The Minnesota Department of Employment and Economic Development is requesting proposals for grants to local communities to increase the supply of quality child care providers in order to support regional economic development. Proposals are due by 4:00 p.m., November 3, 2017. To apply, send a copy of the proposal in PDF format via email to brandon.toner@state.mn.us with the subject line "Child Care Grant Proposal - [Organization Name]". You can find more information available online here: Grant and Contract Opportunities website This Week in American History [cid:image014.png@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] On October 25, 1941, author Anne Tyler was born in Minneapolis. She published over 20 popular novels including The Accidental Tourist, Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant, and Breathing Lessons, for which she was awarded the 1989 Pulitzer Prize for fiction. Spotted in the Seventh [cid:image015.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] Can YOU guess what was Spotted in the Seventh? Each week, the newsletter will feature a landmark or site somewhere in Western Minnesota. The first person to name the location wins! The location of the photo as well as the winner will be revealed in the next newsletter. This week's landmark is run by 30 brave volunteer fireman and won the Minnesota State Fire Department Association's 2014 Fire Department of the Year award... Congratulations to Dan Sartell of Wadena, who was the first to correctly identify our last location as the home of Sinclair Lewis in Sauk Centre! Share your guess on our website - [cid:image016.jpg@01D34F3F.05ABDE80] "Untitled" Carlie Swart (RENVILLE) ######################################################################## To unsubscribe from the NEWSLETTER-MN07 list, click the following link:

body: Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email   /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin: 0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; }      News from Representative Ryan Costello                             Thank you for reading my weekly e-newsletter, Ryan’s Report. This was a District Work Week and I spent time traveling around our community to make site visits and meet with constituents.   I took this photo along the way: French Creek at Sheeder Hall Bridge, East & West Vincent Township, Chester County Since coming to office in 2015, I have heard from constituents, first responders, treatment facility officials, nurses, doctors, and many others who are working to combat the opioid epidemic both locally and nationally. I have utilized their feedback and worked to fight this epidemic through legislation, by ensuring first responders and others facing the epidemic on the front lines have adequate resources, by visiting treatment centers in the community, and by supporting the 21st Century Cures Act, which provided $1 billion in funding for states to fight the opioid epidemic - including $26 million for Pennsylvania alone. As you may have read, or seen on 60 Minutes, the intent and focus of legislation regarding the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) that was signed into law in 2016 was recently the subject of a Washington Post story.This bipartisan legislation first passed through the Energy and Commerce Committee’s Health Subcommittee and the full Energy and Commerce Committee unanimously in 2014 and 2015 before it passed both the House and Senate unanimously -in fact, it passed the House unanimously in 2014, 2015, and 2016- and was signed into law by the Obama Administration without any stated objection from the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA). To be clear, this bill went through regular order, and technical assistance was provided by the DEA and Department of Justice (DOJ). Here is an op-ed by Senator Hatch which reflects the facts and the context surrounding passage of the bill. The legislation’s clear and stated intent was to have the DEA and distribution companies establish a clear understanding of enforcement standards, allowing for greater collaboration among stakeholders to address modern challenges to prescription drug abuse, while still allowing patients with medical needs to have reasonable access. I have stated that if the purpose of the law is now not being realized, then we need to fix it. I am in the process of investigating and evaluating this, and preparing questions to the DEA to get answers. I believe many others are as well, especially given it was unanimously supported by the entire Congress and signed into law by President Obama. On Wednesday, October 25, I will have the opportunity to hear directly from the DEA during a full Energy and Commerce Committee hearing. I will be sure to provide an update from the hearing. Keep reading for a full update on my week. October 16 – October 20: Local Efforts to Keep Our Community Safe & Healthy Week Without Domestic Violence I joined the YWCA Tri-County on Thursday for its Open House for National Week Without Violence - a nationwide effort to raise awareness on the impact of violence in our communities. I believe it is critical to advocate for healthy and safe communities, which is why I support efforts in Congress on these important issues:   Increasing Opportunity and Success for Children and Parents through Evidence-Based Home Visiting Act: This legislation reauthorizes the Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) Program, which relies on evidence-based measures by ensuring grantees of the program are making progress in several areas, including improvements in maternal health, improvements in self-sufficiency, reduction of child abuse, and reducing domestic violence. Under the bill, states must provide certain information to show this progress.    International Violence Against Women Act: This bill would create an Office of Global Women’s Issues within the U.S. Department of State. In addition, this legislation would establish a Senior Coordinator for Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment within the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). If enacted, these programs would be directed to coordinate U.S. foreign policy with respect to the global prevention of violence against women and girls. This legislation would help promote gender integration on an international scale, especially in countries where women are denied basic human rights, starved of opportunity, and unjustly targeted as victims of discrimination and abuse.   PAWS Act: This bill would amend federal criminal law to include threats or acts of violence against an individual’s pet under the offenses of stalking and interstate violation of a protection order. In addition, this legislation would authorize the U.S. Department of Agriculture to award grants to local stakeholders to develop programs to provide housing assistance, support services, and training for victims of domestic violence and their pets.  I also sent a bipartisan letter with Congresswoman Debbie Dingell (D-MI) to U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos, urging her to maintain Title IX guidance in K-12 schools that protects young people from sexual assault and harassment. Our schools must be prepared to protect students from sexual assault and violence, which is why maintaining current guidance to make sure schools know their responsibilities and commit to them is so important. The lasting consequences for victims of sexual assault can be wide-ranging, which is just one of the reasons why we must ensure schools support completing training and education to provide an environment safe from sexual violence. You can read the letter here. When Secretary DeVos announced the Department would rescind Title IX guidance, I issued the following statement: At the very least, parents expect Pennsylvania’s K-12 schools, colleges, and universities to be safe learning environments for our students, and Title IX helps uphold this standard. Any threats to a safe and healthy learning environment – especially sexual misconduct – must be taken seriously and addressed swiftly and fairly. I am concerned by Secretary DeVos' decision today to formally rescind the 2011 Title IX guidance document issued by the Department of Education that protects young people from sexual assault and harassment. I will continue paying close attention to the Department’s actions as it reevaluates existing guidance to improve due process under the law. Any new guidance must maintain strong protections for victims, further clarify the responsibilities of schools under Title IX, and more effectively prevent sexual assault on campus. Infrastructure In Our Community  This week, I visited Poplar Neck Bridge in Cumru Township to meet with officials from the American Public Works Association (APWA) and local officials about infrastructure needs. In Congress, I co-chair the Public Works and Infrastructure Caucus – a bipartisan forum to advance discussion and efforts on the need for greater investment in our nation’s infrastructure, including public works. I believe our Caucus can play a vital role in advocating for a comprehensive infrastructure package and serving as a strong advocate for public works throughout that process. Public works professionals are the first line of defense in weather emergencies and natural disaster to make sure our roads are safe and clear for first responders – and who provide vital services we all depend on day in and day out, regardless of where we live. Equifax Update As I continue to hear from constituents affected or concerned by the data breach at Equifax, caseworkers at my offices in West Chester and Wyomissing are available to provide assistance for residents of Pennsylvania's Sixth Congressional District. As a reminder, you may also visit the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) website for assistance by clicking here. I am also continuing to work on this issue in Congress: This week, along with my colleagues on the Energy and Commerce Committee, I sent a letter to the General Services Administration (GSA) requesting information on GSA’s data security evaluations when considering and awarding federal contracts. The Committee was made aware GSA had previously awarded federal contracts to Equifax, including for data work with the Internal Revenue Service, Social Security Administration and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.   Companies that handle consumers’ personal information as part of their work with the federal government must demonstrate an ability to protect this sensitive information as part of the contract application process - no excuses. Similarly, federal agencies vetting potential contractors should have a strong confidence in those companies’ ability to securely guard such information. I also recently signed onto a letter sent to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) that questioned the decision by the IRS to continue its contract for data services with Equifax even after the breach. The IRS has since suspended the contract. Click here to read the letter to GSA and click here to read the letter to the IRS. I will continue to keep you updated on this issue.  Constituent Service Announcements Pottstown Office Hours  Did you know my office holds Community Office Hours at the Pottstown Library? A member of my staff will be in Pottstown on the first and third Thursday of each month, and is available to meet with constituents between 11:00 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. Spotted Lanternfly I have been hearing from constituents about the Spotted Lanternfly, a pest that could negatively impact the operations of farms in our area, particularly in Berks County, as well as recreation and daily routines for constituents. Earlier this year, Pennsylvania received federal funding through the Farm Bill to help respond to the Spotted Lanternfly. I am currently working with federal officials at the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) on how we can provide effective assistance. If you need immediate assistance regarding the pest, or have questions, please click here for additional information.  October: Breast Cancer Awareness Month This year, approximately 246,600 women in the U.S. will be diagnosed with breast cancer. In Pennsylvania, approximately 30 new cases are diagnosed each day. With the National Institutes of Health (NIH) estimating that 1 in 8 women will receive a breast cancer diagnosis at some point during her lifetime, we all know someone who has been affected. As we recognize Breast Cancer Awareness Month this October as part of the nationwide effort to support those who have been impacted by breast cancer and to raise awareness to improve early detection, I wanted to tell you about my efforts in Congress to combat this disease:  Accelerating the End of Breast Cancer Act: This bill would take steps to identify opportunities and ideas within government and the private sector that have not yet been utilized but could be very helpful in the work to end breast cancer.   Breast Cancer Patient Education Act: This bill would take steps to better inform breast cancer patients of treatment and recover options.   Protecting Access to Lifesaving Screenings (PALS) Act: This bill would help women maintain access to essential breast cancer screenings, regardless of their age.  I have also worked to gain the support of a bipartisan group of my colleagues to advocate for robust funding for the Department of Defense Breast Cancer Research Program during the appropriations process and will be sure to share the letter with you once it has been sent. Next week, the House will be in session for votes, Committee business, and constituent meetings. Sincerely,  Ryan Costello Member of Congress               The Alexander-Murray plan, a bipartisan health plan announced this week in the Senate, would provide for two years of cost-sharing reduction payments, a new plan level that allows for catastrophic insurance, an increase in state flexibility through certain waivers, and fiscal responsibility through a "zero score." What are your thoughts on this plan?I support parts of the plan, but I still want to see the Affordable Care Act (ACA) repealed and replaced. I support parts of the plan and believe additional fixes are necessary, but we should keep the ACA. I support parts of the plan, but I still believe single-payer is the way forward. I do not support any parts of the plan announced this week and believe the only solution is to repeal and replace the ACA. I do not support any parts of the plan announced this week and believe the only solution is a single payer healthcare system. I do not support any changes to the ACA. I'm not sure      Here I am visiting the YWCA Tri-County on Week Without Violence for the YWCA's open house - a nationwide effort to raise awareness on the impact of violence in our communities. In this photo, I am with Stacey Woodland, Chief Executive Officer. Click here to watch WFMZ's coverage of the open house.  I joined the Greater Berks Food Bank (GBFB) this week for the World Food Day Breakfast - an opportunity to thank the dedicated volunteers, staff, and supporters and raise awareness of the importance of addressing hunger. It may be hard to believe food insecurity exists in your own backyard – but thirteen percent of the population in Berks County lives in poverty and can face food insecurity – including many children. We must raise awareness and advocate for solutions to this problem, and GBFB is playing an important role in helping the community. Click here for more information.  Constituents with the Recording Academy visited my office to talk with me about music licensing.  Katherine, a member of my Washington, D.C. staff, met with Ayanna Mitchell, a student at Pottsgrove High School and Pennsylvania’s Student Ambassador with Fuel Up To Play 60. Ayanna shared her day-to-day responsibilities with the FUTP60 program and how she engages with other students, teachers, school administrators, and cafeteria staff to promote health and wellness at school. She was recently awarded a $1,000 grant for her proposal to reduce food waste in school cafeterias. Congratulations, Ayanna, and thank you for taking the time to visit my office to share your ideas on issues of importance to you and your fellow students!   As part of an effort to bring new residents and work opportunities to Pottstown, the Pottstown Industrial Development Authority and other community organizations brought together dozens of business owners, residents and community leaders to record a promotional video touting the community’s civic pride, along with the slogan, I Pick Pottstown.  Meeting with doctors and healthcare professionals at Reading Hospital to listen to their concerns about improving access and quality of care for their patients.  Exciting day for students, staff, school board and the community as Boyertown Area School District formally unveiled renovated high school after a three-year building project. Beautiful fall afternoon to celebrate and get a look at all the hard work that went into making a great school even better.  I met with the Pennsylvania Institute of Certified Public Accountants to discuss tax reform and other legislative priorities. ICYMI: Pottstown Mercury: Rep. Ryan Costello: Protecting access to the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) Click here to read my op-ed. ICYMI: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security recently provided updated guidance on Pennsylvania’s extension for REAL ID implementation and what that means for Pennsylvanians when they travel. The extension is through October 10, 2018. Click below for further information. For more information, click here.                            Washington DC  326 Cannon H.O.B. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin: 0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; }    p { margin-bottom:1em; }      Monday Report from Representative Rick Nolan                                             Congress Must Repeal a Bad Law Fueling America’s Opioid Crisis    Union members protest pharmaceutical company profits from opioid shipments that fall into the wrong hands. Dear Friend,  Opioid pain killer abuse kills some 33,000 Americans every year, and I’m strongly supporting legislation to immediately repeal a bad law that has made the opioid crisis even worse. Under the guise of ensuring adequate supplies to patients who actually require these powerful medications, the 2016 law has made it tougher for federal enforcement agencies to crack down on drug companies and distributors that ship opioids illegally to turn huge profits. According to a blockbuster investigation by the Washington Post and 60 Minutes, these shipments have flooded areas of the Nation hardest hit by the opioid abuse epidemic. So in addition to repealing the 2016 law, our new measure restores the federal Drug Enforcement Agency’s (DEA) full authority to suspend the licenses of unscrupulous distributors of opioids and other prescription drugs.  Last week, President Trump’s nominee to be the Nation’s “Drug Czar,” Republican Congressman Tom Marino, was forced to withdraw from consideration following news reports that he had received substantial campaign contributions from the pharmaceutical industry while helping lead the 2016 measure to passage by the House. In fact, according to the Post-60 Minutes report, the pharmaceutical industry spent more than $100 million lobbying Congress and delivering campaign contributions between 2014 and 2016. This is just one more example of the toxic effects of special interest money on our public policymaking process. That’s why my Restore Democracy legislation calls for getting toxic special interest money out of politics. We need to restore integrity to a system that has increasingly become rigged for the rich and powerful.  As this opioid situation so clearly illustrates, bad public policy fueled by special interests and their campaign dollars not only hurts our Nation – but can also cost lives. The American people deserve better from their elected leaders.  We will keep you posted as events proceed. Meanwhile, I want to hear your thoughts. Feel free to contact any of our offices listed below or send me an email. Sincerely,   International Falls Military Veterans Roundtable Highlights Need to Reform Veterans Choice Program    Click on the photo above for a video summary of the packed military Veterans roundtable Minnesota Congressman Tim Walz and I hosted last Friday in International Falls. Congressman Walz, to my left in this picture, is the highest ranking enlisted person ever to serve in Congress. No military Veteran should ever have to make a 600-mile round trip from International Falls to Minneapolis for routine medical care. That, in a nutshell, was the message Minnesota Congressman Tim Walz and I heard last week from Veterans Service Officers, health care providers, and military Veterans who attended our Veterans Choice roundtable on Friday in International Falls.   The Veterans Choice program to provide rural military Veterans with top quality local medical care – without having to travel long distances to VA health care facilities – is a great idea. But Veterans Choice is not working as intended. Rules and regulations are confusing. Providers are leaving the system because of trouble getting paid. And it takes too long to schedule appointments. So we need to be bold, creative, and open to new ideas in order to fix Veterans Choice and get it right.   As we pointed out during the meeting, the Veterans Affairs Administration (VA) has just submitted its latest version of Veterans Choice reform legislation to the House and Senate Veterans Affairs committees - an update which is meant to eliminate the current long wait times and distance requirements that have frustrated so many military Veterans and their families.  Congressman Walz is the Ranking Member (Democratic equivalent of Chairman) of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, and I’ll be working closely with him on bipartisan legislation to provide better and more accessible local health care to all our military Veterans in Minnesota and across our Nation.    Military Veterans and their families packed our Veterans Roundtable in International Falls to relay their experiences with the Veterans health care system and advocate for reform of the Veterans Choice program to provide local care in rural areas.   21st Century Cures Act Just One Step Forward To Better Mental Health Diagnosis and Treatment    Wherever I go across Minnesota’s rural 8th District, families, patients, community leaders and mental health professionals emphasize the need for more mental health resources for diagnosis, treatment and support.  By almost any definition, mental health problems here in America have reached epidemic proportion – a major factor in opioid abuse and addiction, alcoholism, domestic abuse, crime, homelessness, unemployment and suicide. According to the National Alliance of Mental Illness, more than 43 million people experience some kind of mental health issue in any given year.   Make no mistake – we are making progress. The 21st Century Cures Act signed into law in 2016 contains a provision I cosponsored – the Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Act – that has been called the most significant attempt at mental health reform in decades.  Specifically, the Cures Act provides money and support to better train teachers, law enforcement, and first responders to recognize the symptoms of mental illness and de-escalate crises. Thanks to the Cures Act, there are more resources to keep people with mental illnesses out of jail, and more psychiatric hospital beds once they get into treatment. The law also provides for better oversight of the insurance industry to ensure that mental illnesses are treated like any other medical condition.   But as I pointed out to the hundreds who attended last week’s Pine County Mental Health Forum in Hinckley, we still have a long way to go to bring mental health issues out into the open, and encourage people to seek treatment. Only about 40 percent of the people who need treatment actually receive it. According to the National Alliance of Mental Illness, that figure translates into annual lost earnings topping $193 billion. And tragically, more than 90 percent of young people who die by suicide have a mental health condition.  Wherever I go across Minnesota’s rural 8th District, families, patients, community leaders and mental health professionals emphasize the need for more mental health resources for diagnosis, treatment and support. And more bed and facilities for people in crisis, so they can be treated close to home near their families and loved ones. That will be my focus in Congress as we strive to make life better for people who are troubled and in need.    Paws & Claws in Hackensack Joins Nationwide Rescue of Pets Made Homeless by Hurricanes    At the Paws and Claws Rescue and Resort in Hackensack, owners Betty and Jack Thomas introduced me to Bruiser, a boxer mix puppy displaced when Hurricane Harvey struck Texas earlier this fall.  This fall’s devastating hurricanes have left countless numbers of pets homeless, and Betty and Jack Thomas, owners of the Paws and Claws Rescue & Resort in Hackensack, have joined folks all over the country to help them out. In addition to providing adoption, foster care and boarding for local dogs and cats, as well as volunteer, educational, and employment opportunities for Cass County animal lovers, Betty and Jack have accepted ten dogs separated for their families when Hurricane Harvey struck Texas.  When I visited Paws and Claws last week, Betty and Jack introduced me to the little guy in the photo above. His name is Bruiser, and he’s a boxer mix puppy. He sure is cute. And he’s also a reminder of the lasting damage that terrible storms bring upon communities. Though the hurricanes have past, an incredible amount of work needs to be done. And as I have pointed out before, Congress must immediately provide the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) with all of the resources and support necessary to help restore Puerto Rico, Texas, and Florida. Tens of thousands of people are still struggling to rebuild their homes, regain access to power and clean drinking water and - for some - to find their lost pets.  Thanks to Betty and Jack and folks like them, thousands of homeless pets are finding safe haven, and as many as possible are being reunited with their families. You can find more information on how to help by clicking HERE.    GOP Opens the Way for $1.5 Trillion Tax Boondoggle to Make the Rich Even Richer - Working Families Would Pay the Bill     House and Senate Republicans have passed a budget resolution that opens the way for an enormous tax cut for super-wealthy individuals and corporations - paid for by working families. Republicans leaders have again demonstrated that they will stop at nothing to hand millionaires, billionaires and wealthy corporations a $1.5 trillion tax cut paid for by working families. Paving the way for the GOP’s phony so-called “tax reform” bill, Senate Republicans last week passed a $4 trillion budget resolution that would blow up the deficit and roll back Social Security, Medicare, and an entire century of American progress. On the chopping block are good paying jobs, clean air and water, lifesaving medical research, pensions and retirement benefits, health care and transportation – just to name a few.  As I have pointed out before, the Republican budget plan sets the stage for dismantling Social Security and Medicare - turning Social Security over to Wall Street bankers and Medicare over to the costly private insurance industry. Medicare benefits would be cut by half a trillion dollars.  And Medicaid – which millions of elderly nursing home patients, disabled children, rural hospitals and others depend on for support – would be decimated with a trillion dollar cut. Now the GOP Senate measure goes back to the House, where Republican leaders will do their utmost to rubber stamp it. Mark my words – I will continue to fight this every step of the way. And I’ll be working for a much better budget that invests in America, in people and good paying jobs, and in opportunities for the middle class.      Our Week in Cook   It was a tremendous honor for me to present 96-year-old World War II Navy Veteran Leo Hiveley with several medals he earned in service to our Nation. The medal pinning ceremony took place at the Cook VFW on Friday afternoon. A mix-up way back in 1945 prevented Leo from receiving the honors at that time, and I’m so proud that our Congressional office was instrumental in rectifying the situation so he could receive them in front of so many friends and members of his family. Our Week in Minneapolis   My daughter Katherine and I were honored to represent A Breath of Hope Lung Foundation at a special luncheon sponsored by the Minnesota Vikings and the American Cancer Society to honor cancer survivors and caregivers. Here we are with Viking team member Jaleel Johnson, one of many players we met at this wonderful event. Our Week in International Falls   Before our Veterans Roundtable with Congressman Tim Walz, I sat down for an interview with host Duane Etienne at KSDM/KGSM Radio.   During our tour of the beautiful new terminal at International Falls Airport, I had the opportunity to meet with the TSA Homeland Security agents who do such great work to ensure the safety of passengers and employees alike. I’m proud to say that our office helped secure $3 million in federal funding for this facility, which will help boost good paying jobs, commerce and tourism throughout the Borderland.  Our Week in Blackduck   We enjoyed a warm welcome from the 300 employee owners of Anderson Fabrics, Blackduck’s largest employer - and the largest custom fabrics design and craft center in the Nation. Blackduck Mayor Rudy Patch and City Administrator Christina Regas joined us on Thursday afternoon for the tour.  Our Week in Crosby    I’m working hard in Congress to increase funding for medical research to help better diagnose, treat and ultimately find a cure for Type 1 Diabetes. So it was a real inspiration to meet with Crow Wing Commissioner Doug Houge, who has launched the “Because of Brandon” campaign to help find a cure and boost awareness of this condition. Doug lost his son, Brandon, to type 1 diabetes in 2015. For the past two years, he has worked to raise more than $90,000 to send children with this disease to a special summer camp, and to help parents transport their kids to doctor visits in the Twin Cities. Doug is pictured here along with Jayce, a Type 1 Diabetes survivor who is helping advance the Because of Brandon organization. Our Week in Duluth   The Duluth Chamber of Commerce’s 147th Annual Meeting on Thursday night. The speaker was our friend Khawar Nasim, Consul General of Canada stationed in Minneapolis.  Mr. Nasim spoke about the important trade relationship that Canada and the United States share. Canada is Minnesota’s largest trading partner. Anyone who spends anytime in Duluth, on the Iron Range or North Shore, has seen all of those Canadian license plates and knows what a positive impact our friends to the North have on our economy.  When we talk about fair trade and free trade, we need to make sure we protect our good relationship with Canada. Our district director, Jeff Anderson, attended the event on my behalf.     Members of the Baha'i in the Northland gathered over the weekend to celebrate the 200th anniversary of their faith, and Nolan Congressional staffer Brynn Sias joined them on my behalf.  I was proud to co-sponsor a House Resolution this year condemning the Government of Iran for their state-sponsored persecution of their Baha'i minority. Our Week in Pequot Lakes   Highway 317 is open! Staff from MnDOT, Mathiowetz Construction and WSB Engineering were on hand to celebrate the completion of the Highway 371 expansion project. In this picture, Pequot Lakes Mayor, Nancy Adams, cuts the ribbon to officially open the highway. Nolan Congressional Field Representative Tiffany Stenglein attended the event on my behalf. Our Week in Hackensack    At the Paws and Claws Rescue & Resort, my old friends Jack and Betty Thomas, who operate this wonderful facility, introduced me to Eddie, a rescue cat they have adopted as their own. Eddie is one lucky guy!   Our Week in Littlefork   We stopped in Littlefork on Thursday for a tour of the Littlefork/Rainy Lake Medical Center and meeting with the staff to discuss rural health care issues. Pictured here with me are Stephanie Fairchild, Dietary Manager; Geoffrey Ryan, Regional Director St. Francis; Carrie Claybuny, Associate Administrator; Deputy Mayor of Littlefork Loren Lehman; Ron Manka, Director of Maintenance. Our Week in Hinckley   These Green Bay Packer fans were among the several hundreds folks who attended the Pine County Mental Health Forum last Tuesday in Hinckley.   Coming Up in Washington  This week: The House is expected to take up the fiscal 2018 budget resolution that the Senate adopted last week. If the House green lights what the Senate sent over, the Senate would be able pass their tax overhaul for the wealthy with a simple majority.  Finally... Sunrise on No-Ta-She-Bun Lake   Click on the screen above to see the beautiful video Nolan Congressional Field Representative Jordan Metsa captured last week of the sun rising on No-Ta-She-Bun Lake in Itasca County. The lake is up to 45 feet deep and encompasses 238 acres.                 Washington, D.C.  2366 Rayburn HOB Washington, D.C.20515 Tel: (202) 225-6211 Fax: (202) 225-0699  Duluth Office  Duluth Technology Village 11 E. Superior St., #125 Duluth, MN 55802 (218) 464-5095  Brainerd Office  Brainerd City Hall 501 Laurel Street Brainerd, MN 56401 (218) 454-4078  Chisholm Office  Chisholm City Hall 316 W.
